PREFACE 
    The Franklin, Indiana, Municipal Code has been kept current by regular supplementation by Municipal Code Corporation, its successor in interest. 
    During original codification, the ordinances were compiled, edited and indexed by the editorial staff of Matthew Bender & Company, Inc. 
    The code is organized by subject matter under an expandable three-factor decimal numbering system which is designed to facilitate supplementation without disturbing the numbering of existing provisions. Each section number designates, in sequence, the numbers of the title, chapter, and section. Thus, section 2.12.040 is section .040, located in chapter 2.12 of title 2. In most instances, sections are numbered by tens (.010, .020, .030, etc.), leaving nine vacant positions between original sections to accommodate future provisions. Similarly, chapters and titles are numbered to provide for internal expansion. 
    In parentheses following each section is a legislative history identifying the specific sources for the provisions of that section. This legislative history is complemented by an ordinance disposition table, following the text of the code, listing by number all ordinances, their subjects, and where they appear in the codification; and beginning with Supplement No. 5, legislation can be tracked using the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
    A subject-matter index, with complete cross-referencing, locates specific code provisions by individual section numbers. 
    This supplement brings the Code up to date through Ordinance 2017-11, passed January 8, 2018. 
Municipal Code Corporation 
1700 Capital Circle SW 
Tallahassee, FL 32310 
800-262-2633 
HOW TO USE YOUR CODE 
    This code is organized to make the laws of the city as accessible as possible to city officials, city employees and private citizens. Please take a moment to familiarize yourself with some of the important elements of this code. 
Numbering System. 
    The numbering system is the backbone of a Code of Ordinances; Municipal Code Corporation uses a unique and versatile numbering structure that allows for easy expansion and amendment of this Code. It is based on three tiers, beginning with title, then chapter, and ending with section. Each part is represented in the code section number. For example, Section 2.04.010 is Section .010, in Chapter 2.04 of Title 2. 
Title. 
    A title is a broad category under which ordinances on a related subject are compiled. This code contains about 15 to 20 titles. For example, the first title is Title 1, General Provisions, which may contain ordinances about the general penalty, code adoption and definitions. The titles in this code are separated by tabbed divider pages for quick reference. Some titles are Reserved for later use. 
Chapter. 
    Chapters deal with more specific subjects, and are often derived from one ordinance. All of the chapters on a related subject are grouped in one title. The chapters are numbered so that new chapters which should logically be placed near certain existing chapters can be added at a later time without renumbering existing material. For example, Chapter 2.06, City Manager, can be added between 2.04, City Council, and Chapter 2.08, City Attorney. 
Section. 
    Each section of the code contains substantive ordinance material. The sections are numbered by "tens" to allow for expansion of the code without renumbering. 
Tables of Contents. 
    There are many tables of contents in this code to assist in locating specific information. At the beginning of the code is the main table of contents listing each title. In addition, each title and chapter has its own table of contents listing the chapters and sections, respectively. 
Ordinance History Note. 
    At the end of each code section, you will find an "ordinance history note," which lists the underlying ordinances for that section. The ordinances are listed by number, section (if applicable) and year. (Example: (Ord. 272 § 1, 1992).) 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 5, a secondary ordinance history note will be appended to affected sections. Ordinance history notes will be amended with the most recent ordinance added to the end. These history notes can be cross referenced to the code comparative table and disposition list appearing at the back of the volume preceding the index. 
Statutory References. 
    The statutory references direct the code user to those portions of the state statutes that are applicable to the laws of the municipality. As the statutes are revised, these references will be updated. 
Cross-Reference Table. 
    When a code is based on an earlier codification, the cross-reference table will help users find older or "prior" code references in the new code. The cross-reference table is located near the end of the code, under the tabbed divider "Tables." This table lists the prior code section in the column labeled "Prior Code Section" and the new code section in the column labeled "Herein." 
    As of Supplement No. 5, this table will no longer be updated. 
Ordinance List and Disposition Table. 
    To find a specific ordinance in the code, turn to the section called "Tables" for the Ordinance List and Disposition Table. This very useful table tells you the status of every ordinance reviewed for inclusion in the code. The table is organized by ordinance number and provides a brief description and the disposition of the ordinance. If the ordinance is codified, the chapter (or chapters) will be indicated. (Example: (2.04, 6.12, 9.04).) If the ordinance is of a temporary nature or deals with subjects not normally codified, such as budgets, taxes, annexations or rezones, the disposition will be "(Special)." If the ordinance is for some reason omitted from the code, usually at the direction of the municipality, the disposition will be "(Not codified)." Other dispositions sometimes used are "(Tabled)," "(Pending)," "(Number Not Used)" or "(Missing)." 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 5, this table will be replaced with the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
Code Comparative Table and Disposition List. 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 5, a Code Comparative Table and Disposition List has been added for use in tracking legislative history. Located in the back of this volume, this table is a chronological listing of each ordinance considered for codification. The Code Comparative Table and Disposition List specifies the ordinance number, adoption date, description of the ordinance and the disposition within the code of each ordinance. By use of the Code Comparative Table and Disposition List, the reader can locate any section of the code as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
Index. 
    If you are not certain where to look for a particular subject in this code, start with the index. This is an alphabetical multi-tier subject index which uses section numbers as the reference, and cross-references where necessary. Look for the main heading of the subject you need, then the appropriate subheadings: 
BUSINESS LICENSE 
See also BUSINESS TAX 
Fee 5.04.030 
Required when 5.04.010 
    The index will be updated as necessary when the code text is amended. 
Insertion Guide. 
    Each supplement to the new code will be accompanied by an Insertion Guide. This guide will tell the code user the date of the most recent supplement and the last ordinance contained in that supplement. It will then list the pages that must be pulled from the code and the new pages that must be inserted. Following these instructions carefully will assure that the code is kept accurate and current. Removed pages should be kept for future reference. 
Page Numbers. 
    When originally published, this code was numbered with consecutive page numbers. As it is amended, new material may require the insertion of new pages that are numbered with hyphens. (Example: 31, 32, 32-1.) Backs of pages that are blank (in codes that are printed double-sided) are left unnumbered but the number is "reserved" for later use. 
Electronic Submission. 
    In the interests of accuracy and speed, we encourage you to submit your ordinances electronically if at all possible. We can accept most any file format, including Word, WordPerfect or text files. If you have a choice, we prefer Word, any version. You can send files to us as an e-mail attachment, by FTP, on a diskette or CD-ROM. Electronic files enable us not only to get you your code more quickly but also ensure that it is error-free. Our e-mail address is: ords@municode.com . 
For hard copy, send two copies of all ordinances passed to: 
Municipal Code Corporation 
P.O. Box 2235 
Tallahassee, FL 32316 
Customer Service. 
    If you have any questions about this code or our services, please contact Municipal Code Corporation at 1-800-262-2633 or:

Title 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 1.04 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

1.04.010 - Interpretation. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this code, or by law or implication required, the same rules of construction, definition and application shall govern the interpretation of this code as those governing the interpretation of the Indiana Code. 
(Amended during 2005 codification; prior code § 10.02) 
1.04.020 - Jurisdiction. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this code, this code applies to acts performed within the corporate limits of the city, and to acts performed outside the corporate limits where the law confers power on the city to regulate such acts, up to the limits prescribed by law. 
(Prior code § 10.03) 
1.04.030 - Definitions. 
A.  Words and phrases shall be taken in their plain or ordinary and usual sense. But technical words and phrases having a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be understood according to their technical import. 
B.  Terms used in this code, unless otherwise defined, have the same meanings prescribed by the statutes of the state for the same terms. 
C.  For the purposes of this code the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    "City" means the city of Franklin, Indiana. 
    "Code" means the City of Franklin Municipal Code. 
    "Council" or "common council" means the common council of the city. 
    "County" means the county of Johnson, Indiana. 
    "Indiana Statutes" means the latest publication thereof. 
    "May" means the act referred to is permissive. 
    "Month" means a calendar month. 
    "Officer," "board" or "commission" means, where not otherwise specified, an officer, board or commission of the city. 
    "Ordinances" means the ordinances of the city and all amendments thereto, including this code. 
    "Owner," applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership or joint tenant of the whole or a part of the building or land, either alone or with others. 
    "Person" means any individual, firm, partnership, corporation, company, association, club, joint venture, estate, trust or any group or combination acting as a unit and the individuals constituting the group or unit. As applied to partnerships or associations, the word "person" includes the members thereof; as applied to corporations it includes the officers, agents or employees responsible for the act referred to. 
    "Personal property" means every species of property except real property. 
    "Population" means and refers to the population according to the most recent federal special or decennial census or corrected population count effective under IC 1-1-3.5. This definition applies even if the reference is to the most recent federal decennial census. 
    "Property" means real and personal property. 
    "Real property" means lands, tenements and hereditaments and all chattels real. 
    "Shall" means the act referred to is mandatory. 
    "Sidewalk" means that portion of a street between the curb lines of the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    "State" means the state of Indiana. 
    "Street" means, except as provided in Title 10 of this code, the entire width between property lines of every way or place of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right. 
    "Year" means a calendar year, unless otherwise expressed; equivalent to the words "year of our Lord." 
(Amended during 2005 codification; prior code § 10.05) 
1.04.040 - Rules of interpretation. 
    The construction of all ordinances of this city shall be by the following rules, unless such construction is plainly repugnant to the intent of the legislative body or of the context of the same ordinance: 
A.  "And" or "Or." Either conjunction shall include the other as if written "and/or," if the sense requires it. 
B.  Acts by Assistants. When a statute requires an act to be done which, by law, an agent or deputy as well may do as the principal, the requisition shall be satisfied by the performance of the act by an authorized agent or deputy. 
C.  Gender-Singular and Plural-Tenses. Words denoting the masculine gender shall be deemed to include the feminine and neuter genders; words in the singular shall include the plural and words in the plural shall include the singular; the use of a verb in the present tense shall include the future, if applicable. 
D.  General Term. A general term following specific enumeration of terms is not to be limited to the class enumerated unless expressly so limited. 
E.  Joint Authority. Words importing joint authority to three or more persons shall be construed as authority to a majority of such persons, unless otherwise declared in the law giving such authority. 
(Prior code § 10.08) 
1.04.050 - Severability. 
    Each chapter, section and division of a section of the code hereby adopted, is declared to be independent of every other chapter, section or division of a section and the invalidity of any chapter, section or division of a section of the code shall not invalidate any other chapter, section or division of a section thereof. 
(Prior code § 10.09) 
1.04.060 - Reference to offices. 
    Reference to a public office or officer shall be deemed to apply to any office, officer or employee of the municipality exercising the powers, duties or functions contemplated in the provision, irrespective of any transfer of functions or change in the official title of the functionary. 
(Prior code § 10.11) 
1.04.070 - Errors and omissions. 
    If a manifest error is discovered, consisting of the misspelling of any words; the omission of any word or words necessary to express the intention of the provisions affected; or the use of a word or words to which no meaning can be attached; or the use of a word or words when another word or words was clearly intended to express the intent, the spelling shall be corrected and the word or words supplied, omitted or substituted as will conform with the manifest intention, and the provisions shall have the same effect as though the correct words were contained in the text as originally published. No alteration shall be made or permitted if any question exists regarding the nature or extent of the error. 
(Prior code § 10.12) 
1.04.080 - Official time. 
    The official time, as established by applicable state and federal law, shall be the official time within the city for the transaction of all city business. 
(Prior code § 10.13) 
1.04.090 - Reasonable time. 
A.  In all cases where an ordinance requires an act to be done in a reasonable time or requires reasonable notice to be given, "reasonable time or notice" means the time which is necessary for a prompt performance of such act or the giving of such notice. 
B.  The time within which an act is to be done, as provided in this section, shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last. If the last day is Sunday, it shall be excluded. 
(Prior code § 10.14) 
1.04.100 - Ordinances saved. 
    All ordinances of a temporary or special nature and all other ordinances pertaining to subjects not embraced in this code shall remain in full force and effect unless repealed expressly or by necessary implication. 
(Prior code § 10.16) 
1.04.110 - Responsibility for acts. 
    Every person concerned in the commission of an act prohibited by this code, whether he or she directly commits the act, or prosecutes, counsels, aids or abets in its commission, may be prosecuted and on conviction is punishable as if he or she had directly committed the act. 
(Prior code § 10.18) 
Chapter 1.08 - CORPORATE BOUNDARIES 
Sections: 

1.08.010 - Established. 
    The corporate boundaries of the city are established pursuant to the current "Current Corporate Boundaries Map" maintained in the department of planning and economic development. 
(Ord. 05-12 § 1; prior code § 11.01) 
1.08.020 - Authority of planning department. 
    Due to the ever-changing nature of the city's corporate boundaries, the department of planning is authorized to alter to the "Current Corporate Boundaries Map" as needed. All alterations to such map must be reported to the board of public works and safety. 
(Ord. 05-12 § 2) 
1.08.030 - Public access. 
    The "Current Corporate Boundaries Map" shall be maintained at the offices of the department of planning and economic development and shall be accessible for public review during normal operating hours. 
(Ord. 05-12 § 3) 
Chapter 1.12 - COMPREHENSIVE PLAN ADOPTED 
Sections: 

1.12.010 - Adoption of comprehensive plan. 
    A comprehensive plan, two copies of which are on file in the office of the clerk-treasurer of the city, being marked and designated as the comprehensive plan, is adopted as the comprehensive plan of the city and declaring all of the parts thereof as therein provided in the comprehensive plan, above referred to, now on file in the office of the clerk-treasurer, a part of this code, as if fully set out in this chapter. 
(Prior code § 151.01) 
1.12.020 - Copies available for inspection. 
    Copies of the comprehensive plan on file in the office of the clerk-treasurer are available for public inspection during normal business hours. 
(Prior code § 151.02) 
Chapter 1.16 - GENERAL PENALTY 
Sections: 

1.16.010 - General penalty-Enforcement of ordinances-Collection of monetary fines. 
A.  These provisions relative to the enforcement of ordinances involving the imposition of monetary fines for violations establishes the procedure by which the city will seek the collection of the monetary fines so imposed. The use of these procedures for collecting fines may be used separately or in conjunction with other legal remedies available to the city, such as the pursuit of injunctive relief. 
B.  The city officer, employee or other representative, charged with the duty and authority to issue citations for alleged violations of applicable city ordinances, rules and regulations, that involve, in whole or in part, the imposition of monetary fines (referred to hereafter as the "citing officer"), will as soon as practicable after the issuance of the citation, provide on a form prescribed by the clerk-treasurer the name and address of the person so cited, as well as other relevant information, such as date of citation, the amount of the fine as imposed by ordinance and a brief description of the violation. In those cases where the condition that prompted the citation continues unabated from day-to-day, the citing officer will issue the citation for each day of the continuing violation and will report each such citation to the clerk-treasurer as a separate violation. The citing officer's department head and the clerk-treasurer may use their sound discretion to administer this transfer of information from the citing officer to the clerk-treasurer. 
C.  The clerk-treasurer will maintain a record of citations forwarded to him or her from citing officers and collect from the persons so cited voluntary payments made by them of the fines associated with their violations. The clerk-treasurer is authorized to track and administer the payment and nonpayment of violations as he or she deems appropriate, including, but not limited to, employing the use of case management tools or other relevant tracking software and/or seeking the assistance of other city departments, including the police department and/or planning department (with their administrative capabilities) and/or Franklin city court (and its fines/payments capabilities). 
D.  Persons who fail to pay all of the fines imposed upon them within thirty (30) days of the citation being issued will be included in a list of unpaid citations (referred to hereafter as the "list") compiled by the clerk-treasurer and presented to the board of works as soon as practicable and routinely during the board of works' first meeting of each month. 
E.  The board of works will review the list, make any changes to the list that are warranted under the circumstances and forward the list, as revised, if at all, to the city attorney for enforcement. 
F.  The city attorney is authorized to take those measures reasonably necessary to prosecute and collect from those persons included on the list the fines imposed for such violations, as well as reasonable attorneys' fees and costs of the action. Additionally, the city attorney may seek all other relief for the city that is available, including where appropriate and permitted by law, injunctive relief, imposition of pre-judgment attachments and foreclosure of post-judgment liens and restrictions of the person's driving privileges. The city attorney is authorized to enlist the assistance of the Johnson County prosecutor's office, attorneys representing individual city departments and/or other attorneys when such additional enforcement assistance furthers the efficiency and efficacy of the city's enforcement actions. In such cases, the Johnson County prosecutor's office and/or the other attorneys enlisted by the city attorney will work in conjunction with the city attorney to avail the city of all available enforcement remedies. The city attorney will provide the board of works with a periodic report of enforcement activity. 
G.  Unless another penalty is specifically provided for in any particular section of this code, the monetary penalty imposed for each incidence of a violation of this code or any rule or regulation adopted pursuant or by reference thereto is the lesser of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) or that limit imposed by applicable law, plus reasonable attorneys' fees and costs of collection, where permitted. Other relief permitted by operation of ordinance or other law may be pursued in addition to the monetary penalty set forth in this section. 
H.  The penalties and procedures provided in this section apply to all ordinances, amendments and adoptions by reference thereto, irrespective whether a monetary penalty is specifically provided for in the other ordinance, amendments or adoptions thereto. 
(Ord. 04-05 § 1 (part): prior code § 10.99 (part)) 
Chapter 1.20 - Economic Development Target Areas 
Sections: 

1.20.010 - Designation of downtown Franklin as economic development target area. 
    The geographic area shown on Exhibit "A" attached to Ord. No. 09-13, commonly referred to as "Downtown Franklin", is designated an "Economic Development Target Area" pursuant to Indiana Code § 6-1.1-12.1-7. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 1, 10-5-2009) 
Title 2 - ADMINISTRATION AND PERSONNEL 
Chapter 2.04 - CITY COUNCIL 
Sections: 

2.04.010 - Councilmembers. 
A.  The number of members of the common council shall be seven and the members of the common council shall be known as members of common council. 
B.  Candidates for the office of councilmember shall be nominated and elected in accordance with IC 36-4-6-2, 36-4-6-4 and 3-5-1-1 et seq. 
(Prior code § 30.01) 
2.04.020 - Division of city into five districts. 
    The city shall be divided into five council districts for the purposes of electing council members. 
    The five council districts are described as follows: 
(1)  District 1 (Ward #1): Beginning at the intersection of the centerline of East King Street at its intersection with the centerline of the right-of-way of the Louisville & Indiana Railroad; then east along the centerline of East King Street to the east line of Precinct Franklin 5 (east boundary line of 1065 King Street); then south along the centerline of Precinct Franklin 5 to its intersection with the centerline of Park Avenue; then northwesterly along the centerline of Park Avenue to its intersection with the centerline of Grizzly Drive; then west along the centerline of Grizzly Drive to the centerline of Branigin Boulevard; then southeasterly along the centerline of Branigin Boulevard to its intersection with the centerline of East South Street; then west along the centerline of East South Street to the centerline of Youngs Creek; then following westerly along the centerline of Youngs Creek to its intersection with the centerline of Walnut Street (extended); then north along the centerline of Walnut Street (extended) to its intersection with the centerline of King Street; then west along the centerline of King Street to the centerline of North Morton Street (U.S. 31); then northerly along the centerline of U.S. 31 to its intersection with the centerline of Canary Ditch; then northeasterly along the centerline of Canary Ditch to its intersection with the centerline of the right-of-way of the Louisville & Indiana Railroad; then southeasterly along the centerline of the right-of-way of the Louisville & Indiana Railroad to the point of beginning. 
(2)  District 2 (Ward #2): Beginning at the intersection of the centerline of the right-of-way of the Louisville & Indiana Railroad at its intersection with East King Street; then east along the centerline of East King Street to the east line of Precinct Franklin 5 (east boundary line of 1065 King Street); then south along the east line of Precinct Franklin 5 to the centerline of East Jefferson Street; then east along the centerline of East Jefferson Street to its intersection with the centerline of Milford Drive; then north along the centerline of Milford Drive to the centerline of East King Street; then east along the centerline of East King Street to the eastern boundary of the City; then following the boundary of the City northerly and westerly to its intersection with the centerline of the right-of-way of the Louisville & Indiana Railroad (north of Commerce Drive); then following the centerline of the right-of-way of the Louisville & Indiana Railroad southeasterly to the point of beginning. 
(3)  District 3 (Ward #3): Beginning at the intersection of the centerline of North Morton Street (U.S. 31) at its intersection with West King Street; then east along the centerline of West King Street to the centerline of Walnut Street; then south along the centerline of Walnut Street to its intersection with the south right-of-way line of West Jefferson Street; then southwesterly along the centerline of the utility right-of-way to its intersection with the centerline of Youngs Creek; then southwesterly along the centerline of Youngs Creek to the centerline of South Morton Street (U.S. 31); then northerly along the centerline of South Morton Street to the centerline of West Jefferson Street; then westerly along the centerline of West Jefferson Street following the City boundary westerly, northerly and easterly to the centerline of Simon Road (East 175 North); then easterly along the centerline of Simon Road to the centerline of Galaxy Drive; then southerly along the centerline of Galaxy Drive to the centerline of Acorn Boulevard; then southerly along the centerline of Acorn Road/Acorn Boulevard to the centerline of Oakleaf Road; then southeasterly along the centerline of Oakleaf Road to the centerline of Westview Drive; then southwesterly along the centerline of Westview Drive to the centerline of Robin Road; then southerly along the centerline of Robin Road to the centerline of Canary Ditch; then easterly and northerly along the centerline of Canary Ditch to the centerline of Westview Drive; then easterly along the centerline of Westview Drive to the centerline of North Morton Street (U.S. 31); then southerly along the centerline of North Morton Street to the point of beginning. 
(4)  District 4 (Ward #4): Beginning at the intersection of the centerline of East Jefferson Street with the east line of Precinct Franklin 5 (east boundary line of 1065 King Street); then east along the centerline of East Jefferson Street to the centerline of Milford Drive; then north along the centerline of Milford Drive to East King Street (State Road 44); then east along the centerline of East King Street to the easternmost City boundary; then south, west and north following along the City boundary to the intersection of the centerline of Drake Road with the centerline of West Jefferson Street (State Road 44); then east along West Jefferson Street to its intersection with the centerline of South Morton Street (U.S. 31); then southerly along the centerline of South Morton Street to the centerline of Youngs Creek; then easterly along the centerline of Youngs Creek to the centerline of a utility right-of-way; then northeasterly along the utility right-of- way to the south right-of-way line of Jefferson Street; then south along the centerline of Walnut Street (extended) to the centerline of Youngs Creek; then easterly along the centerline of Youngs Creek to the centerline of East South Street; then east along the centerline of East South Street to the centerline of Branigin Boulevard; then northwesterly along the centerline of Branigin Boulevard to the centerline of Grizzly Drive; then east along the centerline of Grizzly Drive to the centerline of Park Avenue; then southeasterly along the centerline of Park Avenue to the east line of Precinct Franklin 5 (west boundary line of 1200 Park Avenue); then north along the east line of Precinct Franklin 5 to the point of beginning. 
(5)  District 5 (Ward #5): Beginning at the centerline of the right-of-way of the Louisville & Indiana Railroad south of Commerce Drive at its intersection with the centerline of Canary Ditch; then southwesterly along the centerline of Canary Ditch to the centerline of North Morton Street (U.S. 31); then southerly along the centerline of North Morton Street to the centerline of Westview Drive; then west along the centerline of Westview Drive to the centerline of Canary Ditch; then southwesterly along the centerline of Canary Ditch to the centerline of Robin Road; then north along the centerline of Robin Road to the centerline of Westview Drive; then northeasterly along the centerline of Westview Drive to the centerline of Oakleaf Road; then westerly along the centerline of Oakleaf Road to the centerline of Acorn Boulevard; then north along the centerline of Acorn Boulevard/Acorn Road to the centerline of Galaxy Drive; then northerly along the centerline of Galaxy Drive to the centerline of Simon Road; then west along the centerline of Simon Road (East 175 North) to the western City boundary; then following the City boundary north, west, east and south to its intersection with the right-of-way of the Louisville & Indiana Railroad with the centerline of Commerce Drive; then following along the centerline of the right-of-way of the Louisville & Indiana Railroad to the point of beginning. 
    If any part of the city is not included in one of the districts established by this chapter, that territory is included within the district that: 
(1)  Is contiguous to that territory; and 
(2)  Contains the least population (as determined by the most recent census) of all districts that are contiguous to that territory. 
    If any part of the city is included in more than one of the districts established by this chapter, that territory is included within the district that: 
(1)  Is one of the districts in which the territory is described in this chapter; 
(2)  Is contiguous to that territory; and 
(3)  Contains the least population (as determined by the most recent census) of all districts that are contiguous to that territory. 
    The council adopts a map depicting the districts established under this chapter, and incorporates the map attached hereto as Exhibit "A" by reference into this chapter. Two copies of the foregoing map are on file in the office of the clerk-treasurer for public inspection as required by I.C. 36-1-5-4. If a conflict exists between the districts as depicted on the map and as described in this chapter, the description in this chapter prevails. 
(Ord. 06-05 § 1: prior code §§ 30.02, 30.03) 
(Ord. No. 2012-27, §§ 1-5, 12-3-2012) 
Chapter 2.08 - ADMINISTRATIVE REGULATIONS 

2.08.010 - Failure of officers to perform official duties. 
    The failure of any officer or employee of the city to perform any official duty imposed by this code shall not be a violation and shall not subject the officer or employee to the penalty imposed for violation of this code, unless a penalty is specifically provided. 
(Prior code § 32.01) 
2.08.015 - Code of ethics. 
    The following paragraphs apply to all public officials, officers or employees of the City of Franklin, IN. 
    No elected official, officer or employee shall accept gifts or honoraria that individually exceed the value of two hundred dollars ($200.00) or that cumulatively exceed the value of four hundred dollars ($400.00) in any calendar year from any business entity that is doing business with the city and/or a city agency. 
    No elected official, officer or employee shall accept anything of monetary value including any gift, favor, service, entertainment or item that has been solicited by same with the intent to give special consideration or influence as to any action by such elected official, officer or employee in his/her official capacity. Nothing herein shall prohibit the receipt of political and other contributions that are lawful under and reported in accordance with Indiana law and/or which are donated to or accepted on behalf of the city or an agency. 
    For purposes of this policy, gifts or honoraria means money or other property which is transferred to an elected official, officer or employee without reasonable value being provided for same by said elected official, officer or employee but does not include the following: 
(a)  Invitations, tickets, food and drink provided to an elected official, officer or employee or a member of his or her immediate family, during the conduct of official city business or at public ceremonies; or 
(b)  Mementos or souvenirs of nominal value received at public ceremonies or commemorating official city business; or 
(c)  Invitations or tickets to political fundraising dinners or public events when used by an elected official, officer or employee or a member of his or her immediate family; or 
(d)  Food or drink consumed by an elected official, officer or employee in connection with official city business at a convention, reception or gathering of other public officials and/or municipal employees; or 
(e)  Travel or other expenses paid or reimbursed as a result of speaking engagements, educational training or personal appearances made as a result of or by virtue of an elected official's, officer's or employee's official position or duties; or 
(f)  Donations made to the city which are not designated to a specific elected official, officer or employee including but not limited to door prizes given in connection with a city-approved training or celebration; or 
(g)  An award, plaque, certificate or similar personalized memento given in recognition of the employee's public, civic, charitable or professional service; or 
(h)  An honorary membership in a service or fraternal organization presented merely as a courtesy by such organization; or 
(i)  The use of a public facility or public property, made available by a governmental agency, for a public purpose; or 
(j)  Discounts given to members of a particular class of individuals irrespective of employment with the city such as public service or public safety discounts. 
    Additionally, as required by Federal Highway Administration and the Indiana Department of Transportation and as applicable only to receipt of federal transportation funds, the city does hereby adopt the conflict of interest policy for an official or employee who participates in the selection or in the award or administration of a contract of any INDOT contract. Officials and employees of the city participating in the selection or overseeing the administration of a federal highway or INDOT contract shall comply with the following code of ethics: 
CODE OF ETHICS 
1.  Prohibits employees participating in decision making and circumstances where the employee, officer or agent, employees partner, family member or an organization that employs or is about to employ any of the listed persons would have a potential financial interest in the outcome. 
2.  Consider the interest of the state and INDOT when contracting for professional services. 
3.  Seek to obtain the maximum value for each dollar spent for professional services. 
4.  Request removal from any situation which a personal relationship may affect judgement in selection, administration or performance evaluation activities. 
5.  Avoid unnecessary sharing of internal INDOT information, including project or program information that may result in giving a competitive advantage to a select firm or firms. 
6.  Accept nothing of monetary value from consultants, potential consultants or parties to agreement with the exception of mementos or souvenirs of nominal value which may be accepted. 
    This Code of Ethics and Conflict of Interest Policy maybe amended from time to time as approved by the city council and a copy of said Code of Ethics and Policy should be included in the City of Franklin Employee Manual. 
(Ord. No. 2017-11, 1-8-2018) 
2.08.020 - Additional compensation of officials. 
    The officials of the city, both elected and appointed employees of the city who perform services for the city, other than governmental, whose services are connected with the operation of any municipally owned utility or function, may receive additional compensation for their services and this additional compensation shall be determined and fixed by the administrative authority in control of the operation of the utility or function, subject to the approval of the mayor and the common council. Any additional compensation so authorized shall be paid from the revenue derived from the operation of the utility or function. 
(Prior code § 32.02) 
2.08.030 - Control and management of municipal cemetery. 
    Pursuant to IC 23-14-65-9, the control and management of the municipal cemetery is transferred to the Franklin Parks Board. 
(Prior code § 33.03) 
(Ord. No. 12-06, 2-20-2012) 
2.08.050 - Designated depositories. 
    The clerk-treasurer of the City of Franklin, Indiana is hereby authorized to deposit, invest, and reinvest monies, as determined and identified by the clerk-treasurer, in the following designated financial institutions in Franklin, Indiana: Fifth Third Bank, First Financial Bank, Heartland Community Bank and/or any other financial institution identified eligible by the Indiana Board of Depositories. 
(Ord. No. 12-01, 2-6-2012; Ord. No. 13-01, 2-4-2013) 
2.08.060 - Internal Control Standards. 
    The city of Franklin adopts as policy the Internal Control Standards as set forth by the Indiana State Board of Accounts Uniform Internal Control Standards for Indiana Political Subdivisions Manual as expressly written and published by the Indiana State Board of Accounts in September 2015, and as amended from time to time. In order to implement these standards, the city clerk-treasurer shall certify in writing that personnel as defined in statute have received the required training. All officers, elected officials and employees are required to comply with the policy. Employees who fail to comply with this policy are subject to discipline, including but not limited to, termination of their employment. 
(Ord. No. 2016-04, § 4, 3-21-2016) 
Chapter 2.12 - POLICE DEPARTMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- For regulations concerning police department longevity compensation plans and clothing and equipment allowances, see Sections 2.56.010 and 2.56.020 of this title. 

2.12.010 - Police officers' pension fund. 
    The city elects to establish and create a police officers' pension fund, to be administered by a board of trustees of the police officers' pension fund, in accordance with IC Sections 36-8-6 and 36-8-8. 
(Amended during 2005 codification; prior code § 33.71) 
2.12.020 - Police reserve force. 
A.  There is created a reserve police force for the city which shall be attached to and work under the authority of the police department of the city. 
B.  The number of reserve police officers shall not exceed one-half of the number of regular police officers of the city. 
C.  The reserve police officers shall be appointed by the same authority which appoints regular members of the department and may not be members of the regular police force but shall have all of the same police powers of the members except as limited by the rules of the department. 
D.  Reserve police officers may not participate in any pension program provided for regular members of the police department but may, to the extent that the funds for benefits are appropriated receive a uniform allowance. 
E.  No reserve police officer shall be appointed until he or she has completed the training and probationary periods specified by the rules and regulations of the police department. 
(Prior code § 33.74) 
2.12.030 - Police merit commission. 
A.  Pursuant to IC 36-1-4-14, there is established a police merit commission for the city. 
B.  The police merit commission is established under the authority of IC 36-1-4-14, not under the authority of IC 36-8-3.5-1. 
C.  The following sections of IC 36-8-3.5 are specifically adopted as a part of this section and incorporated herein by reference as though fully set forth herein: IC 36-8-3.5-2; IC 36-8-3.5-6 (other than as specifically excepted hereinafter in subsections (C)(1) and (C)(2) of this Section 2.12.030); IC 36-8-3.5-7 through IC 36-8-3.5-23. These sections of IC 36-8-3.5 shall be fully applicable to the police merit commission in their current form and as they may hereafter be amended, including any recodifications thereof. 
1.  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in IC 36-8-3.5-6 or in this section, the political affiliation of the commissioners of the police merit commission shall be determined by the criteria established by IC 36-1-8-10. 
2.  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in IC 36-8-3.5-6 or in this section, a commissioner of the police merit commission must have been a legal resident of the city for not less than one continuous year immediately preceding the commissioner's appointment. 
(Prior code § 33.76) 
(Ord. No. 2015-08, § 1, 9-21-2015) 
Chapter 2.16 - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- For regulations concerning fire department longevity compensation plans and clothing and equipment allowances, see Sections 2.56.010 and 2.56.020 of this title. 

2.16.010 - Firefighters' pension fund. 
    The city, which maintains a regularly organized and paid fire department, elects to establish a firefighters' pension fund and a board of trustees to manage the pension fund, under the terms and provisions of IC Chapters 36-8-7 and 36-8-8. 
(Amended during 2005 codification; prior code § 33.46) 
2.16.020 - Charge for ambulance service outside the city. 
    Any person who resides outside the corporate boundaries of the city, who requires or requests the assistance, services or use of the ambulance provided by the city and the fire department, and which assistance, service or use causes the ambulance to travel outside the corporate boundaries of the city shall be charged the amount of three hundred dollars ($300.00). The amount charged shall be per person who utilizes the services of the ambulance, not merely per run. 
(Prior code § 33.49) 
2.16.030 - Fire merit commission. 
A.  Pursuant to IC 36-1-4-14, there is established a fire merit commission for the city. 
B.  The commission is established pursuant to authority granted in IC 36-1-4-14 and not established pursuant to IC 36-8-3.5-1. 
C.  The following sections of IC 36-8-3.5 are specifically adopted as a part of this section and incorporated herein by reference as though fully set forth herein and such sections of the statutes shall be fully applicable to the fire merit commission as such sections now exist, or as they may be hereafter amended: IC 36-8-3.5-2, 36-8-3.5-6 through 36-8-3.5-23. 
(Prior code § 33.50) 
2.16.040 - Career firefighters. 
A.  The fire department shall consist of not less than thirty-four (34) career firefighters. 
B.  Vacant career firefighter positions shall be filled by the fire merit board within a reasonable amount of time. 
(Prior code § 33.51) 
2.16.050 - Charge for fire service to non-taxpaying entities. 
A.  The city's common council, with the advice of the chief of the fire department, will by annual resolution determine a fair user fee or other payment mechanism ("fee") to be charged to and paid by non-taxpaying entities that receive fire service from the city. 
B.  The application, imposition and collection of the fee will be administered by the board of works, which is granted the discretion to prospectively or retroactively waive or adjust the fee in cases of undue hardship or other just cause. 
C.  Non-taxpaying entities may appeal the establishment, application or collection of the fee as follows: 
1.  Appear in person or by a duly authorized representative at a regularly scheduled board of works meeting within thirty (30) days of receiving notice of the imposition of the fee to show why an undue hardship or other just cause exists to reduce or waive the fee. The board of works may, in its discretion, reduce, waive or otherwise adjust the application or collection of the fee in response to the entity's request. 
2.  If the board of works' response to the entity's request is unacceptable to the entity, a duly authorized representative of the entity may appear at a regularly scheduled common council meeting within thirty (30) days of verbally or otherwise receiving the board of works' response to its request, to show why an undue hardship or other just cause exists to reduce or waive the fee. The common council may, in its discretion, reduce, waive or otherwise adjust the application of the fee to the entity or its collection. The decision of the common council is final as to the request. 
D.  The board of works is expressly empowered to contract on behalf of the city with private and public entities for the provision of fire service. The board of works is empowered to pursue collection of the fee and any contract payments through all legal remedies. 
E.  The actions of the board of works, mayor and chief of the fire department relative to the establishment, application and collection of fees and contracts for fire service taken prior to the enactment of the ordinance codified in this section are approved, ratified and adopted as if they had been taken subsequent to and in furtherance of the ordinance codified in this section. The current fee and contract provisions established by the board of works, mayor and chief of the fire department are adopted as the initial fee and contract provisions, and when applicable, will be reviewed and revised as necessary in June 1998 and yearly thereafter. 
(Prior code § 33.52) 
Chapter 2.20 - PARK AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT 
Sections: 

2.20.010 - Establishment of department and board-Composition. 
A.  There is established a department of parks and recreation, to be operated and controlled by the parks and recreation board, which department and which board shall operate under and be governed by the provisions of IC 36-10-3-1 et seq. 
B.  There is established the park and recreation board. The board shall be composed of four members whose initial terms shall be one, two, three and four years. Thereafter, as a term expires, each appointment shall be for a term of four years. All terms shall expire on the first Monday in January and each member shall continue in office until his or her successor is appointed and qualified. The mayor shall appoint the four members of the board, but not more than two members shall be of the same political party. The board of school trustees and the library board shall appoint one of their members who shall be ex-officio members of the board. The term of an ex-officio member shall be co-extensive with the term of his or her office unless the board shall, at its first regular meeting of any year, appoint another to serve as its representative. 
(Prior code § 33.60) 
2.20.020 - Officers-Meetings. 
A.  At its first regular meeting in each year the park and recreation board shall elect a president and a vice-president. The board may elect a secretary either from within or without its own membership. 
B.  The board shall fix the time and place of its meetings, but it shall meet at least quarterly during each year. Three members shall constitute a quorum and action of the board is not official unless authorized by three members present and acting. All meetings shall be public and shall be held in quarters furnished by the common council. 
(Prior code § 33.61) 
2.20.030 - Powers. 
    The park and recreation board shall have the following powers and duties: 
A.  Exercise general supervision of and make regulations for the park and recreation department and establish rules governing the use of the parks and recreation facilities by the public. 
B.  Provide police protection for its property and activities, either by requesting assistance from state, city, or county police authorities, or by having specified employees deputized as police officers. The deputized employees, however, shall not be eligible for police pension benefits or other emoluments of police officers. 
C.  Make contracts and leases for facilities and services, but shall have no authority to contract with persons or private agencies for the operation of a park recreation program. 
D.  Acquire and dispose of real and personal property either within or without this state. 
E.  Exercise the power of eminent domain under the authority of IC 32-11-1-1 et seq. 
F.  Appoint administrative officers of the department as are necessary, fix their duties and compensation, and delegate authority to perform ministerial acts in all cases except where final action of this board is necessary. 
G.  Establish standards and qualifications of all personnel, fix their compensation, and approve their appointments without regard to political considerations. 
H.  Contract for special and temporary services and for professional assistance. 
I.  Make recommendations and an annual report to the mayor and council concerning the operation of the board and the status of parks and recreation programs within its jurisdiction. 
J.  Prepare, publish and distribute reports and other materials relating to activities authorized by this act. 
K.  Sue and be sued collectively by its legal name, styled "Franklin city park and recreation board"; service of process being had upon the president of the board; but no costs shall be taxed against the board or its members in any action. 
L.  Invoke any legal, equitable or special remedy for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter or the board's own action taken thereunder. 
M.  Prepare and submit an annual budget in the same manner as other departments of the city government. 
(Prior code § 33.62) 
2.20.040 - Superintendent. 
A.  The administration of the park and recreation department shall be performed by the superintendent of parks and recreation, who shall be appointed by the park and recreation board. The superintendent shall be qualified by training or experience in the field of parks and recreation and shall possess a license or an advanced degree in the field of parks and recreation. The board shall give no consideration to political affiliations in the selection of the superintendent. 
B.  It shall be the duty of the superintendent of parks and recreation to do the following: 
1.  Propose annually a plan for the operation of the park and recreation department; 
2.  Administer the plan as approved by the park and recreation board; 
3.  Supervise the general administration of the department; 
4.  Keep the records of the department and be responsible for the custody and preservation of all papers and documents of the department; 
5.  Recommend persons for appointment as assistants where the board determines there is a need; 
6.  Appoint the employees of the department, according to the standards and qualifications fixed by the board and without regard to political affiliation, subject to the approval of the board; 
7.  Prepare and present to the board an annual report; and 
8.  Perform any other duties as the board may direct. 
C.  When the board determines that the size of the department's operation requires it, they may appoint one or more assistants whose qualifications shall be determined upon a basis similar to that of the superintendent. The assistant shall be directly responsible to the superintendent and shall exercise authority and shall perform duties as specified by the superintendent. 
(Prior code § 33.63) 
2.20.050 - Transfer of property-Appropriations. 
A.  All property, books, papers and documents of prior park and recreation organizations shall be transferred to and become the property of the park and recreation board. 
B.  The common council shall provide the revenue necessary for the operation of the park and recreation department or for capital expenditures or both by a specific levy to be used for this purpose exclusively or by special appropriation or both. 
(Prior code § 33.64) 
Chapter 2.24 - DEPARTMENT OF ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT 
Sections: 

2.24.010 - Creation. 
    There is created in the city a department of economic development, pursuant to IC 36-7-12-1 et seq. to be known as the "Franklin economic development commission." 
(Prior code § 33.35) 
2.24.020 - Appointment-Terms of commissioners. 
    The department of economic development shall be governed by a board of five members, to be appointed by the mayor, as follows: three of the members so appointed shall be selected by the mayor; one shall be selected by the county council; and one shall be selected by the common council. The commissioners so appointed shall take office upon their appointment and their terms shall run the following number of years from February 14, 1972: the commissioner selected by the common council, two years; the commissioner selected by the county council, one year; two commissioners selected by the mayor, three years; one commissioner selected by the mayor, one year from February 1st after their appointment. At the expiration of the respective terms of each of the commissioners originally appointed, their respective successors shall be selected and nominated in the same manner as the original appointee, each of which nominees shall be appointed by the mayor within ten (10) days after receiving such nomination, and each succeeding member will serve for a term of four years. In the event any person appointed as commissioner shall fail to qualify as provided in this chapter within ten (10) days after the mailing to him or her of the notice of his or her appointment, or if any member after qualifying shall die, resign or vacate the office, or be removed as provided in this chapter, a new member shall be chosen and appointed to fill the vacancy in the same manner as provided for the member in respect to whom the vacancy occurred and the member chosen and appointed shall serve for the remainder of the vacated term. 
(Prior code § 33.36) 
2.24.030 - Compensation-Qualifications of commissioners. 
A.  The commissioners shall receive no salaries but shall be entitled to reimbursement for any expenses necessarily incurred in the performance of their duty. 
B.  No person shall be appointed as a commissioner who is not either a resident of the city, employed in the city, or the owner of a business in the city. If any commissioner shall cease to qualify in one of the above categories, his or her appointment on the economic development board shall terminate and his or her office shall become vacant. Each commissioner, before entering upon his or her duties shall take and subscribe an oath of office in the usual form, to be endorsed upon the certificate of his or her appointment, which shall be promptly filed with the clerk-treasurer. 
(Prior code § 33.37) 
2.24.040 - Officers-Meetings-By-laws. 
A.  The economic development commission originally appointed shall meet within thirty (30) days after its appointment at a time and place designated by the mayor, for the purpose of organization and shall meet to reorganize in the month of February of the succeeding year. The commission shall elect one of its members as president, one as vice-president and one as secretary, each of which shall serve from the day of his or her election until January 31st next following his or her election and until his or her successor is elected and qualified. 
B.  The commission is authorized to adopt all by-laws, rules and regulations as it may deem necessary for the proper conduct of its proceedings, the carrying out of its duties, and the safeguarding of the funds and property placed in its custody. Regular or special meetings shall be held at any time as it may determine and upon any notice as it may fix, either by resolution or in accordance with the provisions of the by-laws, rules and regulations adopted. A majority of the commission shall constitute a quorum and the concurrence of a majority shall be necessary to authorize any action. 
(Prior code § 33.38) 
2.24.050 - Powers. 
    The economic development commission shall have all powers, privileges and duties as provided by IC 36-7-12-1 et seq. and as granted by all acts of the Indiana General Assembly heretofore or hereafter enacted. 
(Prior code § 33.39) 
Chapter 2.28 - DEPARTMENT OF REDEVELOPMENT 
Sections: 

2.28.010 - Creation. 
    There is created the department of redevelopment of the city, which shall be entitled to exercise all the rights, powers, privileges and immunities accorded IC 36-7-14. 
(Prior code § 33.97) 
2.28.020 - Redevelopment commission. 
A.  The department of redevelopment of the city shall be under the control of a board of five members to be known as the city redevelopment commission. 
B.  There is created a board to be known as the city redevelopment commission. Three of the commissioners shall be appointed by the mayor and two shall be appointed by the common council. Each redevelopment commissioner shall serve for one year from the first day of January after his or her appointment and until his or her successor is appointed and has qualified, except that the original commissioners shall serve from the date of their appointment until the first day of January in the second year after their appointment. If a vacancy occurs, a successor shall be appointed in the same manner as the original commissioner and the successor shall serve for the remainder of the vacated term. 
C.  Each redevelopment commissioner, before beginning his or her duties, shall take and subscribe an oath of office in the form prescribed by law, to be endorsed on the certificate of his or her appointment, which shall be promptly filed with the city clerk-treasurer. 
D.  Each redevelopment commissioner, before beginning his or her duties, shall execute a bond payable to the state or city with surety to be approved by the mayor. The bond must be in a penal sum of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) and must be conditioned on the faithful performance of the duties of his or her office and the accounting for all moneys and property that may come into his or her hands or under his or her control. The cost of the bond shall be paid by the city, to be reimbursed by the redevelopment district. 
E.  The redevelopment commissioners shall have the qualifications prescribed by state law and shall qualify as therein provided; and shall exercise and enjoy the rights and powers and assume the duties and obligations conferred and imposed by IC 36-7-14, including, but not limited to the following qualifications: 
1.  A redevelopment commissioner must be at least eighteen (18) years of age and must be a resident of the city. If a commissioner ceases to be qualified under this section, he or she forfeits his or her office. 
2.  No redevelopment commissioner shall receive a salary, but redevelopment commissioners are entitled to reimbursement for expenses necessarily incurred in the performance of their duties. 
3.  A redevelopment commissioner may not have a pecuniary interest in any contract, employment, purchase or sale made under the provisions of this section and IC 36-7-14. However, any property required for redevelopment purposes in which a commissioner has a pecuniary interest may be acquired, but only by gift or condemnation. A transaction made in violation of this section is void. 
(Prior code § 33.98) 
2.28.030 - Funds and accounts. 
    The city clerk-treasurer, charged by law for the performance of duties in respect to the funds and accounts of the city, shall perform the same duties with respect to the funds and accounts of the department of redevelopment, except as otherwise provided in IC 36-7-14. 
(Prior code § 33.99) 
Chapter 2.32 - CITY COURT 
Sections: 

2.32.010 - Establishment of city court. 
A.  The city court existing on January 1, 1981, shall be continued until December 31, 1983, and shall be the same city court as established by this chapter. 
B.  From and after January 1, 1984, the following is enacted. 
1.  A city court for the city is established; 
2.  The election for the judge of the city court established by this chapter shall be held in the general election during November of 1983. 
(Prior code § 31.01) 
2.32.020 - City judge. 
A.  Creation. There is created the office of city judge for the city. 
B.  Qualifications. The person elected to the office of city judge shall be a resident of the city and be a member in good standing of the bar and admitted to practice before the Supreme Court of the state. 
C.  Election-Term. The city judge shall be elected at the city election each year in accordance with the provisions of the law now or hereinafter in effect for a term as provided by law. The city judge shall exercise powers and duties of the office as provided for under IC 33-10.1-2 et seq. 
D.  Salary and Expenses. It shall be the duty of the proper officers of the city to include in the annual budget of the city each year, for the following year, the amount of salary to be fixed by ordinance for the office of the city judge, as by law now provided, and the necessary expenses of the office, including, but not limited to secretarial expense, salary for a bailiff and clerk of the city court, and administrative funds to cover docket book, receipt books, check books, stationery expense, and a cash box fund. 
(Prior code § 31.02) 
Chapter 2.44 - REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 
Sections: 

2.44.010 - Creation. 
    Under authority of IC 36-7-14.5, the city creates a redevelopment authority to be known as the "Franklin redevelopment authority" as a separate body corporate and politic and as an instrumentality of the city. 
(Prior code § 33.105) 
2.44.020 - Purpose. 
    The redevelopment authority is organized for the following purposes: 
A.  Financing, constructing and leasing local public improvements to the redevelopment commission; 
B.  Financing and constructing additional improvements to local public improvements owned by the authority and leasing them to the commission; 
C.  Acquiring all or a portion of one or more local public improvements from the commission by purchase or lease and leasing these local public improvements back to the commission, with any additional improvements that may be made to them; 
D.  Acquiring all or a portion of one or more local public improvements from the commission by purchase or lease to fund or refund indebtedness incurred on account of those local public improvements to enable the commission to make a savings in debt service obligations or lease rental obligations or to obtain relief from covenants that the commission considers to be unduly burdensome; and 
E.  Any other purposes permitted by IC 36-7-14.5, including the issuance of bonds to finance local public improvements. 
(Prior code § 33.106) 
2.44.030 - Membership-Terms. 
    The board of directors of the redevelopment authority shall be composed of three members who are residents of the city and shall be appointed by the mayor for three-year terms. 
(Prior code § 33.107) 
Chapter 2.48 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS COUNCIL 
Sections: 

2.48.010 - Created. 
    There is created by this chapter a public body within the government of the city, to be known as the city telecommunications council. 
(Ord. 01-03 § 1) 
2.48.020 - Responsibility to board of public works and common council. 
    The city telecommunications council shall be responsible to, and shall report to, the board of public works and the common council of the city with respect to the duties, responsibilities and authority delineated in this chapter. 
(Ord. 01-03 § 2) 
2.48.030 - Membership-Terms. 
A.  The membership of the council shall consist of five members, a majority of whom must be residents of the city. Subject to the foregoing qualification, members of the council may be residents of the city buffer zone. Two of the members shall be appointed by the mayor. Three of the appointments shall be made by the common council. Efforts shall be made to solicit, as members of the council, individuals with knowledge and expertise in the area of telecommunications, and/or interest in, or commitment to, the area of telecommunications products and service, as well as an interest, desire and commitment to serving the citizens and community of Franklin. 
B.  That the term of council members shall be for a period of four years. However, the initial appointments made by the mayor shall be for a term to expire on December 31, 2004 and the term of the initial appointments by the common council shall be for a term to expire on December 31, 2002. 
(Ord. 01-03 §§ 3, 4) 
2.48.040 - Powers and responsibilities. 
    The Franklin telecommunications council shall have the following powers and responsibilities: 
A.  To evaluate the quality of subscriber service by cable television, telephone or other telecommunications companies. 
B.  To evaluate whether a company is operating in satisfaction of the terms of the telecommunications, telephone products and cable television franchise agreement and applicable state and federal rules and regulations. 
C.  To study the communication needs of the Franklin community and explore ways of using the telecommunications, telephone products and cable television to meet those needs. 
D.  To assist members of the public and non-profit organizations in the use of the telecommunications, telephone products and cable television, including, to the extent of the council's ability, programming advise, production advice and assistance and cable casting arrangements. 
E.  To seek out and retain the services of other persons, organizations and companies for purposes of satisfying the responsibilities assigned to the council by this chapter. 
F.  To report at least once a year, or more frequently upon request, to the mayor, the common council and the board of public works, in writing, on the council's activities and expenditures, such report to include the evaluations provided for in subsections B and C of this section and such report further being made available to the public upon request. Further, to make recommendations and/or suggestions to the board of public works and/or common council of the city in a timely fashion, as appropriate or as requested. 
G.  To make reports and recommendations regarding the creation, establishment, implementation and administration of appropriate municipal Web sites, as well as to seek the best methods of evaluating and improving such sites. 
H.  To make reports and recommendations regarding municipal computer network security and any and all related areas and activities. 
I.  To pursue the preceding responsibilities in the best public interest of the citizens of Franklin. 
(Ord. 01-03 § 5) 
2.48.050 - Election of officers-Rules, regulations and bylaws. 
    The Franklin telecommunications council shall, within thirty (30) days after the initial appointments thereto have been made, meet for an organizational meeting and elect such officers and adopt such rules, regulations and bylaws as the council deems necessary. 
(Ord. 01-03 § 6) 
2.48.060 - Compensation of members-Sources of revenue. 
    The Franklin telecommunications council may provide that its members be compensated at a rate of fifty dollars ($50.00) per month for each month in which the council has at least one formal meeting and may further provide that actual expenses incurred by council members in the furtherance of their duties may be reimbursed, provided however, that the Franklin telecommunications council shall have no authority to incur any debt, pay any per diem, not authorized by the Franklin common council either through the regular budget process or by way of additional appropriation. All funds made available to the Franklin telecommunications council by the Franklin common council shall be from revenues received by the city through the city's franchise agreements with cable service providers and/or other telecommunication product or service providers under contract with the city and from no other source or sources. 
(Ord. 01-03 § 7) 
2.48.070 - Public body-Subject to state statutes. 
    The Franklin telecommunications council is declared to be a public body of the city and therefore is subject to the Indiana Open Door Law and all other statutes, rules and regulations concerning the conduct of public business by units of government in the state. 
(Ord. 01-03 § 8) 
Chapter 2.52 - DEPARTMENT OF ENGINEERING 
Sections: 

2.52.010 - Establishment. 
    Pursuant to Indiana Section 36-4-9-4 and on the recommendation of the mayor, the common council establishes the department of engineering, which is necessary for the efficient performance of the various administrative functions required to fulfill the needs of the city's citizens. 
(Ord. 02-13 § 1) 
2.52.020 - Head of the department-Requirements. 
    The head of the department of engineering will: 
A.  Be the city engineer; 
B.  Be appointed by and serve under the jurisdiction of the mayor; 
C.  Perform the administrative functions assigned by the mayor and board of works, and applicable statutes and ordinances; 
D.  Have a thorough knowledge of modern traffic control methods; 
E.  Be able to supervise and coordinate diversified engineering activities and prepare engineering reports; and 
F.  Within twenty-four (24) months of appointment, be a resident of Johnson County, Indiana. 
(Ord. 02-13 § 2) 
2.52.030 - Head of the department-Duties. 
    As directed by the mayor and board of works, the head of department of engineering will: 
A.  Conduct all research relating to the engineering aspects of the planning of: 
1.  Public ways and works projects; 
2.  Lands abutting public ways and works projects; and 
3.  Traffic operation on public ways; 
    For the safe, convenient and economical transportation of persons and goods; 
B.  Advise the mayor and board of works in the formulation and execution of plans and policies resulting from his or her or her research under subsection A of this section; 
C.  Study all accident records, to which he or she or he or she has access at all times, in order to reduce accidents; 
D.  Direct the use of all traffic signs, traffic signals and paint markings, except on streets traversed by state highways; 
E.  Recommend all necessary parking regulations; 
F.  Recommend the proper control of traffic movement; and 
G.  Supervise all employees engaged in activities described in this chapter. 
(Ord. 02-13 § 3) 
Chapter 2.56 - PERSONNEL REGULATIONS 
Article I. - Police and Fire Departments[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- For additional police department regulations, see Chapter 2.12 of this title. For additional fire department regulations, see Chapter 2.16 of this title. 

2.56.010 - Incorporation of existing police and fire longevity compensation plans. 
A.  All police and fire merit employees employed full-time by the city as of December 31, 2002, will continue to receive in addition to their salary and other benefits the longevity compensation to which they are entitled under the provisions of Ordinance Nos. 81-5 and 735 (relative to police longevity), and Ordinance Nos. 91-3 and 736 (relative to fire longevity), calculated as follows: 
(1)  Two (2) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for two (2) years of service; 
(2)  Four (4) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for four (4) years of service; 
(3)  Six (6) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for six (6) years of service; 
(4)  Eight (8) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for eight (8) years of service; 
(5)  Ten (10) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for ten (10) years of service; 
(6)  Twelve (12) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for twelve (12) years of service; 
(7)  Fourteen (14) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for fourteen (14) years of service; 
(8)  Sixteen (16) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for sixteen (16) years of service; 
(9)  Eighteen (18) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for eighteen (18) years of service; 
(10)  Twenty (20) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for twenty (20) years of service; 
(11)  Twenty-two (22) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for twenty-two (22) years of service; 
(12)  Twenty-four (24) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for twenty-four (24) years of service; 
(13)  Twenty-six (26) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for twenty-six (26) years of service; 
(14)  Twenty-eight (28) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for twenty-eight (28) years of service; 
(15)  Thirty (30) percent of a first-class patrolman or fireman's wages for thirty (30) years of service; 
B.  The years of service mentioned in this section shall include and be allowed only for years spent in actual service as a member of the city's police or fire department. Longevity compensation shall be paid in two (2) installments per year, on or about June 1 and December 1. Longevity compensation will be added to the pay of the members regardless of their rank pay, but longevity compensation shall be based only upon the pay of first-class policemen and firemen. Increases in longevity compensation will be allowed on June 1 and December 1 of each year. Increases will be applied in June if the hire date is between January 1 and May 31 of a two-year qualifying year. Increases will be applied in December if the hire date is between June 1 and December 31 of a two-year qualifying year. 
C.  For the purposes of clarity, this incorporation of the prior longevity compensation plans applies only to policemen and firemen hired by the city on or before December 31, 2002, and does not apply to any policeman or fireman hired by the city on or after January 1, 2003. Further, policemen and firemen hired by the city on or before December 31, 2002, will not receive the longevity compensation described below. 
(Ord. 02-10 § 1(a): prior code §§ 33.45 (part), 33.70 (part)) 
(Ord. No. 08-07, § 1(a), 6-16-2008) 
2.56.020 - Police and fire department clothing and equipment allowance. 
A.  Eligible Members. A clothing and equipment allowance (referred to hereafter as the "Allowance") will be provided to all active merit members of both the Franklin Fire Department and Police Department. Police evidence technician(s) who have been employed at least one full year will receive the allowance. Further, police dispatchers, public safety officer(s) and fire civilian inspector(s) having been employed at least one full year will also receive the allowance, but only in an amount equaling fifty (50) percent of the full allowance. Recipients leaving the city's employ are not entitled to any pro rata share of future allowance payments. 
B.  Amount of Allowance. The full allowance will annually be eight hundred dollars ($800.00). 
C.  Method of Payment. The allowance will be paid in two equal installments, with the first being paid on or about January 10th and the second being paid on or about July 1st of each year. Otherwise, the clerk-treasurer may make the allowance payments in a manner he or she deems appropriate, including by separate check to the eligible employees. 
D.  Approved Clothing and Equipment. A list of approved clothing and equipment will be prepared and periodically amended by the board of works and provided to both the allowance recipients and to the clerk-treasurer. Additionally, the board of works may from time to time add or subtract items from this approved list as the board deems appropriate. 
E.  Taxability of Allowance. The entire allowance is subject to all applicable taxation, including income taxes, social security taxes and/or Medicare taxes, except those portions of the allowance used for qualified and approved uses. Recipients desiring to exempt some or all of their allowance from their taxable income must submit to the clerk-treasurer receipts of approved clothing and/or equipment purchases they have made no later than thirty (30) days before anticipated issuance of the next semi-annual installment payment. To be considered a valid purchase, the receipt must state the date, time, place, amount and business purpose of the purchase(s). The board of works may use its discretion to determine the validity of purchases. Otherwise, applicable income tax withholdings will be made from the employee's next or subsequent wages. 
F.  Directions to Finish 2004. Due to the adoption of the ordinance codified in this section during the course of 2004, the clerk-treasurer is directed to administer the allowance provided by Ordinance No. 87-24 consistent with the terms and provisions of this section. The board of works is authorized to determine on a case-by-case basis in the event that irregularities or inequities develop with respect to the remaining 2004 calendar year. 
(Ord. 04-12 §§ 1-6: prior code §§ 33.48, 33.73) 
(Ord. No. 11-09, 12-19-2011) 
Article II. - General Provisions 

2.56.030 - City-wide longevity compensation plan. 
A.
