[General.] Except as provided above relative to police and fire department merit employees employed by the city as of December 31, 2002, all other city employees, including civilians, policemen, and firemen, will be entitled to receive in addition to their salary and other benefits longevity compensation calculated as follows: 
1.  Upon the completion of one year of full-time employment, city employees will receive one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each year of employment with the city, not to annually exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per employee. 
2.  The years of employment mentioned in this section shall include and be allowed only for years spent in actual employment as a city employee. 
3.  Longevity compensation shall be paid in one installment per year, and will be included in the employee's first full paycheck in January of each year. 
4.  For the purposes of clarity and by way of illustration only, a city employee first hired in August 2003 would receive one hundred dollars ($100.00) as longevity compensation in that employee's first full paycheck in January 2005, because that January 2005 paycheck would be the first January after the employee's hiring anniversary date. 
B.  Longevity Pay to Merit Police Officers and Merit Firefighters After Twenty (20) Years of Service. Police and fire department merit employees employed by the city of Franklin and hired by the city on or after January 1, 2003, shall be entitled to the city wide longevity compensation permitted under subsection A. of this Section 2.56.030 as previously ordained but shall receive in addition to their salary and other benefits the following longevity compensation on the twentieth year of service. 
1.  Twenty (20) percent of a first class patrolman or fireman's wages for twenty (20) years of service; 
2.  In the year in which the merit policeman or merit fireman receives his or her twenty (20) year longevity payment, the police and fire department merit employees shall not receive the one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each year of employment with the city provided in subsection A.1. of this Section 2.56.030; 
3.  The twenty (20) year longevity payment described in subsection (1) above is intended to be a one-time payment made to city of Franklin merit policeman and merit fireman only. 
(Ord. 02-10 § 1(b): prior code §§ 33.45 (part), 33.70 (part)) 
(Ord. No. 08-07, § 1(b), 6-16-2008; Ord. No. 2015-04, § 1, 12-7-2015) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-07, § 1(b), adopted June 16, 2008, amended the catchline of § 2.56.030 to read as herein set out. Said catchline formerly read "Creation of city-wide longevity compensation plan." 
2.56.040 - Withholding for united fund. 
    The clerk-treasurer shall be authorized and empowered to withhold from city employees' pay any amounts designated by the employees to be contributed to the united fund. 
(Prior code § 34.10) 
2.56.050 - Old age survivors insurance. 
A.  The governing body of the city elects coverage under the old age and survivors insurance as provided by IC 5-10.1-1-1 et seq. 
B.  The following positions are designated as those which are to be covered. All positions except the following are designated as those which are to be covered. 
1.  All services of an emergency nature; 
2.  Positions for which the compensation is on a fee basis; 
3.  Part-time positions. Part-time positions are defined as being those positions of employment having less than six hundred (600) hours per calendar year. 
C.  For the purpose of carrying out the provisions of Title 11, Section 218 of the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereof, the agreement entered into between the State Agency with the approval of the Governor and the Social Security Administrator is made a part of this section and shall constitute an integral part of the federal agreement between this political subdivision of the State Agency and shall become a part of the agreement or modification of the agreement between the state and the Social Security Administrator. The governing body explicitly agrees that it will fully perform the obligations of a political subdivision under the federal/state agreement and IC 5-10.1-1-1 et seq. 
(Prior code § 34.11) 
2.56.060 - Reimbursement of certain expenses. 
A.  The mayor is authorized to budget and appropriate funds from the general fund to pay expenses of or to reimburse city officials for expenses incurred in promoting the best interest of the city. These expenses may include, but not necessarily be limited to rental of meeting places, meals, decorations and expenses incurred in interviewing job applicants, promoting industrial development and other expenses of a civic or governmental nature deemed by the mayor to be in the interest of the city. 
B.  The amount of the annual expenditure shall be shown in the annual budget each year and classified as "the mayor's promotional appropriation account." 
C.  Effective January 1, 1988, any elected or appointed official or employee of the city who may find it necessary in the performance of his or her duties to attend workshops, seminars, conferences or similar meetings, shall be reimbursed for the cost of attending the function by the clerk-treasurer upon the proper submission and approval of a claim for the expense. These expenses shall include registration fees, travel expense, food and overnight lodging if necessary. 
(Prior code § 34.12) 
Article III. - Use of City Vehicles and Equipment 

2.56.070 - Use of city vehicles and equipment restricted to authorized personnel. 
A.  Motor vehicles and other equipment owned, leased, possessed or otherwise under the control of the city may be operated only by persons with the legal right to do so. 
B.  City personnel must immediately advise their immediate superior in the event they are without the legal right to operate a motor vehicle or other equipment. 
C.  City personnel will not operate motor vehicles and other equipment owned, leased, possessed or otherwise under the control of the city without the legal right to do so. 
D.  The clerk-treasurer and the department heads of the various city departments are directed to identify all city rules and regulations that are inconsistent with this section, and either amend the inconsistent rules and regulations as necessary or report to the board of works the changes that the board of works should make in order to make all city rules and regulations consistent with this section. 
(Prior code § 34.20) 
Chapter 2.60 - BEAUTIFICATION COMMISSION 
Sections: 
    There is hereby created by this chapter a public body within the government of the City of Franklin, Indiana, to be known as the City of Franklin Beautification Commission. 
(Ord. 08-04, § 1) 

2.60.020 - Duties. 
    The beautification commission shall be responsible to, and shall report to, the board of public works and the common council of the city with respect to the duties, responsibilities, and authority delineated herein. 
(Ord. 08-04, § 2) 
2.60.030 - Membership. 
    The membership of the beautification commission shall consist of five members, a majority of whom must be residents of the city. Subject to the foregoing qualification, members of the beautification commission may be residents of the city buffer zone. Two of the members shall be appointed by the mayor. Three of the appointments shall be made by the common council. Additionally, the beautification commission may retain the assistance and services of volunteer members as needed. 
(Ord. 08-04, § 3) 
2.60.040 - Term. 
    The term of beautification commission members shall be for a period of four years. However, the initial appointments made by the mayor shall be for a term to expire on December 31, 2009, and the term of the initial appointments by the common council shall be for a term to expire on December 31, 2011. 
(Ord. 08-04, § 4) 
2.60.050 - Powers and responsibilities. 
    The beautification commission shall have the following powers and responsibilities: 
A.  To study the beautification needs of the city and explore ways to improve the general aesthetic quality of the city's public improvements; 
B.  To assist members of the public and nonprofit organizations in their efforts to improve the general aesthetic quality of the city's public improvements; 
C.  To seek out and retain the services of other persons, organizations and companies for purposes of satisfying the responsibilities assigned to the beautification commission by this chapter; 
D.  To report at least once a year, or more frequently upon request, to the mayor, the common council, and the board of public works, in writing, on the beautification commission's activities and expenditures. 
E.  To make recommendations and/or suggestions to the board of public works and/or common council of the city in a timely fashion, as appropriate or as requested. 
F.  The beautification commission shall, within thirty (30) days after the initial appointments thereto have been made, meet for an organizational meeting and elect such officers and adopt such rules, regulations and bylaws as it deems necessary. 
G.  The beautification commission shall have no authority to incur any debt or pay any per diem not authorized by the city's common council either through the regular budget process or by way of additional appropriation. 
(Ord. 08-04, § 5) 
Title 3 - REVENUE AND FINANCE 
Chapters: 
Chapter 3.04 - CLAIMS AGAINST THE CITY 
Sections: 

3.04.010 - Approval of claims for payment. 
A.  For items which are in the budget of the common council, it shall be the duty of the common council to approve all claims properly prepared and submitted for the issuance of warrants in payment of such claims. 
B.  For items which are not in the budget of the common council, the common council delegates to the board of public works and safety the duty to approve all claims properly prepared and submitted for the issuance of warrants in payment of such claims. 
(Prior code § 33.02) 
3.04.020 - Clerk-treasurer-Authority to make limited disbursements. 
A.  The clerk-treasurer of the city is authorized and permitted to make payment of claims and obligations for lawful city purposes in advance of formal board of public works confirmation and allowance for the following types of expenses: 
1.  Property or services purchased or leased from: 
a.  The United States Government; or 
b.  An agency or a political subdivision of the United States government; 
2.  License fees or permit fees; 
3.  Insurance premiums; 
4.  Utility payments or utility connection charges; 
5.  Federal grant programs if: 
a.  Advance funding is not prohibited; and 
b.  The contracting party provides sufficient security for the amount advanced; 
6.  Grants of state funds authorized by statute; 
7.  Maintenance agreements or service agreements; 
8.  Lease agreements or rental agreements; 
9.  Principal and interest payments on bonds; 
10.  Payroll and all payroll related expenses including but not limited to pension contributions, credit union contributions, savings bond payments, deferred compensation contributions, FOP dues, and garnishments; 
11.  State and federal taxes; 
12.  Expenses that must be paid because of emergency circumstances; and 
13.  Expenses described in an ordinance. 
B.  Each payment of expenses must be supported by a fully itemized invoice or bill with certification of the clerk-treasurer and the board of public works shall review and allow the claim at the next regular or special meeting following the preapproved payment of the expense. 
C.  Nothing in this section is intended to relieve the clerk-treasurer and/or the board of public works of their responsibilities, duties and obligations generally required with respect to invoices, approvals of invoices, and the proper and lawful disbursement of funds in accordance with the state of Indiana, and the rules and regulations of appropriate agencies thereof. 
(Ord. 00-29 §§ 1-3) 
Chapter 3.08 - PURCHASING SYSTEM 
Sections: 

3.08.010 - Designation of purchasing agency and purchasing agent. 
    The board of public work of the city of Franklin, Indiana is designated as the purchasing agency for the city of Franklin, Indiana with all of the powers and duties authorized under Indiana Code Section 5-22. The purchasing agency will designate in writing a person as the city of Franklin, Indiana's purchasing agent. The purchasing agency may also designate in writing additional purchasing agents as necessary. 
(Ord. 07-05 § 1; amended during 2005 codification) 
3.08.020 - Purchases under fifty thousand dollars. 
    An authorized purchasing agent may purchase supplies with an estimated cost of less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) on the open market without inviting or receiving quotes or bids. 
(Ord. 07-05 § 2) 
3.08.030 - Purchases between fifty thousand dollars and one hundred fifty thousand dollars. 
    An authorized purchasing agent may purchase supplies between fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) and one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) by inviting quotes from at least three persons known to deal in the lines or classes of supplies, goods, or materials to be purchased. With respect to purchases falling with this subsection: 
A.  The purchasing agent shall mail an invitation to quote to the persons known to deal in the lines or classes of supplies, goods, or materials to be purchased at least seven days before the time fixed for receiving quotes. 
B.  If the purchasing agent receives a satisfactory quote, the purchasing agent shall award a contract to the lowest responsible and responsive offeror for each line or class of supplies, goods, or materials required. 
C.  The purchasing agent may reject all quotes. 
D.  If the purchasing agent does not receive a quote from a responsible and responsive offeror, the purchasing agent may purchase the supplies, goods, or materials under the special purchase provisions of the Indiana Code. 
(Ord. 07-05 § 3) 
3.08.040 - Purchase of services. 
    Each city of Franklin, Indiana department, board agency, and commission may purchase services in whatever reasonable manner the purchaser determines, consistent with the foregoing. 
(Ord. 07-05 § 4) 
3.08.050 - Purchase of supplies manufactured in the United States. 
    Supplies manufactured in the United States will be specified for all purchases and will be purchased unless the city of Franklin, Indiana determines: 
A.  The supplies are not manufactured in the United Stated in reasonably available quantities; 
B.  The price of the supplies manufactured in the United States exceeds by an unreasonable amount the price of available and comparable supplies manufactured elsewhere; 
C.  The quality of the supplies manufactured in the United States is substantially less than the quality of comparably priced available supplies manufactured elsewhere; 
D.  The purchase of supplies manufactured in the United States is not in the public interest. 
(Ord. 07-05 § 5) 
Chapter 3.12 - CITY FUND ACCOUNTS 
Sections: 

3.12.010 - Capital improvement fund. 
A.  For the purpose of this section the following definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    "Capital improvements" means the construction or improvement of any property owned by the city, including but not limited to streets, thoroughfares and sewers; the retirement of general obligation bonds issued by the city; and the proceeds used for the purpose of constructing capital improvements. "Capital improvements" shall not include salaries of any public officials or employees except those which are directly chargeable to a capital improvement. 
B.  In accordance with the requirements of IC 6-7-1-30.1 and 6-7-1-31.1, there is created a special fund to be known as the cumulative capital improvement fund of the city into which the cigarette taxes allotted to the city by reason of IC 6-7-1-1 et seq. shall be deposited. The fund shall be a cumulative fund and all of the moneys deposited into the fund shall be appropriated and used solely for capital improvements. None of the moneys shall revert to the general fund or be used for any purposes other than capital improvements. 
(Prior code § 35.01) 
3.12.020 - Park and recreation capital improvement fund. 
    There is created a special nonreverting capital fund for the park and recreation board for park and recreational purposes in acquiring land or making specific capital improvements, major pool repairs or a new swimming pool. The fund shall consist of fees collected with the building permits issued pursuant to the subdivision control ordinance and fees taken at the gate of the Franklin Memorial Swimming Pool which exceeds twenty (20) percent over the annual pool budget. The city clerk-treasurer shall deposit all fees collected in the nonreverting capital fund. 
(Prior code § 35.02) 
3.12.030 - Police department forfeiture fund. 
A.  Creation of Forfeiture Fund. The clerk-treasurer is directed to create a fund into which forfeiture proceeds may be deposited when received from United States Departments of Justice and Treasury, and other local, state and federal agencies as allowed by law, 
B.  Authorized Expenditures from the Forfeiture Fund. The police department is authorized to retain forfeiture proceeds deposited into the fund and expend such proceeds for the following purposes, provided that such expenditures are in compliance with applicable state and federal law and guidelines for the use of equitably shared forfeited property: 
1.  To pay salaries and benefits of law enforcement officers: 
a.  When expressly permitted by law; or 
b.  Hired to replace an officer or officer assigned to a task force for a period of no less than one year or the life of the task force; or 
c.  Assigned to specific approved specialized programs which do not generally involve traditional law enforcement functions, as such programs are periodically specified by the United States Attorney General; 
2.  To pay for law enforcement training, with priority given to training in: 
a.  Asset forfeiture in general; 
b.  The Fourth Amendment; 
c.  Ethics and the National Code for Professional Code for Asset Forfeiture; 
d.  Due process rights; 
e.  Protecting the rights of innocent third-parties; and 
f.  The U.S. Department of Justice's equitable sharing guidelines. 
3.  To pay for law enforcement equipment and operations such as body armor, firearms, radios, cellular telephones, computer equipment and software, vehicles, leasing of equipment for undercover and investigatory purposes; 
4.  To pay for conducting drug education and awareness programs; 
5.  To pay a pro rata share for the police department's use of general, city-owned equipment, property, facilities and other items and services; 
6.  To pay for activities calculated to enhance future investigations, such as the payment of overtimes wages incurred as a result of investigations, payment to informants, "buy", "flash" or "reward" moneys and the purchase of evidence; 
7.  To use not more than fifteen (15) percent of received moneys for the costs associated with drug abuse treatment, drug and crime prevention education, housing and job skills programs or other nonprofit community-based programs or activities which are formally approved by the chief of police as being supportive of and consistent with a law enforcement effort, policy and/or initiative, provided that such use is made by the department making the expenditure and not through the transfer of cash. 
C.  Direction to Clerk-Treasurer. The clerk-treasurer is directed to take those steps necessary to create and administer the forfeiture fund created by this section and effectuate the intent of this section in all respects. 
(Ord. 99-10 §§ 1-3) 
3.12.040 - Record perpetuation fund. 
    The record perpetuation fund is created for use by the city pursuant to Indiana Code § 33-37-5-2, which provides in relevant part as follows: 
A.  The clerk of the Franklin city court shall deposit all the following in the fund: 
1.  Revenue received by the clerk for transmitting documents by facsimile machine to a person under Indiana Code § 5-14-3. 
2.  Document storage fees required under Indiana Code § 33-37-5-20. 
3.  The late payment fees imposed under Indiana Code § 33-37-5-22 of this that are authorized for deposit in the clerk's record perpetuation fund under Indiana Code § 33-37-7-2. 
4.  The fees required under Indiana Code § 29-1-7-3.1 for deposit of a will. 
B.  Upon appropriation, the clerk, at the discretion of the Franklin city court judge, may use any money in the fund for the following purposes: 
1.  The preservation of records. 
2.  The improvement of record keeping systems and equipment. 
3.  Case management system. 
    All fees received and credited to the clerk's record perpetuation fund are to be remitted by the city court to the city-clerk treasurer at the end of each month. 
(Ord. 01-37 § 1) 
(Ord. No. 12-18, §§ 2, 3, 7-2-2012) 
3.12.050 - Fire department-Public education fund. 
    A fund account, to be referred to as the "fire department-public education fund" and given a number or letter designation by the clerk as he or she deems appropriate, is created for use by the city. The fund will segregate and account for contributions made from public and private sources to help defray the cost of the city's fire safety education efforts. The fund is nonreverting and moneys deposited in the fund may only be used for purposes recommended by the fire chief and approved by the board of works. 
(Ord. 04-16 § 1) 
3.12.060 - Rainy day fund. 
A.  Creation. A new fund account, to be referred to as the "rainy day fund", and which is to be given a number or letter designation by the clerk as he or she deems appropriate, is created for use by the city. 
B.  Authorized Use. The fund will segregate and account for contributions and disbursements made pursuant to: 
1.  Indiana Code Section IC 36-1-8-5 and 36-1-8-5.1 relative to funds raised by general or special tax levy; 
2.  Indiana Code Section 6-3.5-1.1-21.1 relative to funds raised by use of a county adjusted gross income tax; 
3.  Indiana Code Section 6-3.5-6-17.3 relative funds raised by use of a county option income tax; 
4.  Indiana Code Section 6-3.5-7-17.3 relative to funds raised by use of capital improvement plans; and 
5.  For other receipts of moneys that are unappropriated and for which direction to the clerk-treasurer by the common council is given for receipt and disbursement of same into the rainy day fund. 
    Accounts maintained in the fund are to be segregated as needed for appropriate administration. The rainy day fund is nonreverting, i.e., balances will not be transferred into other funds, such as the general fund, local road and street or motor vehicle/highway, and all moneys deposited in the rainy day fund may only be used for the purpose agreed upon by the common council. 
(Ord. 04-04 §§ 1, 2) 
3.12.070 - Wireless emergency telephone system fund. 
A.  Creation of "Wireless Emergency Telephone System Fund". The clerk treasurer is directed to create a fund into which PSAP wireless emergency telephone system fund proceeds may be deposited when received from the county auditor as allowed by law. 
B.  Authorized Expenditures from the Wireless Emergency Telephone System Fund: The police department is authorized to expend wireless emergency telephone system fund proceeds deposited into the fund for the lease, purchase, or maintenance of wireless enhanced emergency telephone equipment, including: 
1.  Necessary computer hardware, software, and data base equipment; 
2.  Personnel expense and training; 
3.  The provision of wireless enhanced emergency service; or 
4.  Educating consumers about the operations, limitations, role, and responsible use of enhanced 911 service. 
C.  Direction to Clerk Treasurer. The clerk treasurer is directed to take those steps necessary to create and administer the wireless emergency telephone system fund created by this section, and effectuate the intent of this section in all respects. 
(Ord. 08-08, §§ 1-3) 
3.12.080 - Unsafe building fund. 
    Creation of Unsafe Building Fund. A new nonreverting fund to be known as the unsafe building fund ("fund"), and which is to be given a number or letter designation by the clerk as deemed appropriate, is now established. The fund shall receive monies from any source, including appropriations by local, state, or federal governments, and donations. The fund will be used exclusively for enforcement of chapter 15.12 Dangerous Buildings of the City of Franklin Municipal Code, pursuant to Indiana Code § 36-7-9 et seq. Deposits into and expenditures from the Fund will be administered pursuant to applicable law. 
(Ord. 09-05, § 1) 
Cross reference- Dangerous buildings, Ch. 15.12. 
3.12.090 - Disaster recovery fund. 
    Creation of Disaster Recovery Fund. A new nonreverting fund to be known as the disaster recovery fund ("fund"), and which is to be given a number or letter designation by the clerk as deemed appropriate, is now established. The fund shall receive monies from local, state or federal governments for disaster relief. The fund will be used exclusively for disaster relief under the conditions of Indiana Code § 10-14-3-12. Deposits into and expenditures from the fund will be administered pursuant to applicable law. 
(Ord. 09-06, § 1) 
3.12.100 - Cumulative capital development fund. 
    Creation of Cumulative Capital Development Fund. The Common Council of the City of Franklin establishes a cumulative capital development fund ("CCD fund") for all uses as set out in Indiana Code § 36-9-15.5, including the construction, development, and financing of any public works projects as may be presented from time to time by the mayor to the common council, including, among other things, police structures, fire structures, roads, lighting, remodeling, parking, sidewalks and other similar public amenities. The board will adhere to the provisions of Indiana Code § 36-9-15.5. The proposed fund will not exceed five cents ($0.05) per one hundred dollars ($100.00) of assessed valuation. Said tax rate will be levied beginning with taxes for 2009 payable in 2010. 
(Ord. 09-09) 
Chapter 3.16 - RETURNED CHECK POLICY 
Sections: 

3.16.010 - Returned check policy. 
    In the event that a check made payable to the city of Franklin or one of its departments is returned unpaid or dishonored by the financial institution upon which the check is written: 
A.  The clerk-treasurer will impose a service charge in the amount of the greater of twenty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($27.50) or five percent but not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) of the amount due. 
B.  Notice of the assessment will be sent by the clerk-treasurer to the payor at the address printed on the check, or the address given by the payor in writing to the payee or holder at the time the check was issued or delivered. 
C.  Not later than ninety (90) days after the check is initially received by the city, the clerk-treasurer will refer the matter, if the check and service charge have not been made good, to the Johnson County prosecutor for prosecution. 
D.  Upon the advice of the clerk-treasurer, the board of works may take all other appropriate steps to collect the unpaid check, including the institution of legal process. 
(Ord. 06-10 § 1) 
Title 5 - BUSINESS LICENSES AND REGULATIONS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 5.04 - BUSINESS LICENSES GENERALLY 
Sections: 

5.04.010 - License or permit-Required. 
    No person shall engage in any trade, profession, business or privilege in the city for which a license or permit is required by any provision of this code without obtaining a license or permit from the city in the manner provided in this chapter, unless otherwise specifically provided. 
(Prior code § 110.01) 
5.04.020 - Application-Fee. 
A.  Unless otherwise provided, application for a license or permit shall be made in writing to the clerk-treasurer upon forms provided by the city and the applicant shall state the location of the proposed activity and any other facts as may be required for or be applicable to the granting of a license or permit. 
B.  The fees required for any license or permit shall be paid at the office of the clerk-treasurer before the granting of the license or permit. No fee paid shall be refunded, unless the license or permit is denied. 
(Prior code § 110.02) 
5.04.030 - Bond-Insurance. 
    All required bonds shall be executed by two sureties, or a surety company, and shall be subject to the approval of the mayor. Where policies of insurance are required, the policies shall be approved as to substance and form by the city attorney. Satisfactory evidence of coverage by bond or insurance shall be filed with the city before the license or permit is issued. 
(Prior code § 110.03) 
5.04.040 - License or permit-Approval or denial. 
A.  Where the approval of any city officer or state officer is required prior to the issuance of any license or permit, the approval must be presented to the city before any license or permit is issued. 
B.  No license or permit shall be approved by any city officer or issued by the city if it appears that the conduct of the activity for which a license or permit is sought will be contrary to the health, safety or welfare of the public or any regulation, law or ordinance applicable to this activity. 
(Prior code § 110.04) 
5.04.050 - License or permit-Contents. 
    Licenses or permit certificates shall show the name of the licensee or permittee, the date of issue, the activity licensed and the term of the license or permit, and shall be signed in the name of the city by the mayor and clerk-treasurer and be impressed with the city seal. The clerk-treasurer shall keep a record of all licenses and permits issued. 
(Prior code § 110.05) 
5.04.060 - License or permit-Term. 
    Unless otherwise provided, the term of the license year shall end on June 30th of each year. Where the issuance of licenses for a period of less than one year is permitted, the effective date of the license shall commence with the date of issuance. Permits shall be issued for the term set forth in the permit. 
(Prior code § 110.06) 
5.04.070 - Exhibition. 
    Every licensee or permittee shall carry his or her license or permit certificate upon his or her person at all times when engaged in the activity for which the license or permit was granted, except that where the activity is conducted at a fixed place or establishment, the license or permit certificate shall be exhibited at all times in some conspicuous place in his or her place of business. The licensee or permittee shall exhibit the license certificate when applying for a renewal and upon demand of any police officer or person representing the issuing authority. 
(Prior code § 110.07) 
5.04.080 - Transfer. 
    Unless otherwise provided, no license or permit shall be transferable or assignable. 
(Prior code § 110.08) 
5.04.090 - Renewal. 
    Unless otherwise provided, license or permit renewals shall be issued in the same manner and be subject to the same conditions as original licenses or permits. 
(Prior code § 110.09) 
5.04.100 - Revocation. 
A.  Any license or permit issued by the city may be suspended by the mayor for not more than ten (10) days upon recommendation of a city official. 
B.  Any license or permit may be revoked by the council after a hearing for any of the following causes: 
1.  Fraud, misrepresentation or incorrect statement contained in the application or made in carrying on the licensed or permitted activity; 
2.  Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor applicable to the activity for which the license or permit has been granted; 
3.  Conducting the licensed activity in a manner so as to constitute a breach of the peace; a menace to the health, safety or welfare of the public; or a disturbance of the peace or comfort of residents of the city, upon recommendation of the appropriate city official; 
4.  Expiration or cancellation of any required bond or insurance; 
5.  Actions unauthorized or beyond the scope of the license or permit granted; 
6.  Violation of any regulation or provision of this code applicable to the activity for which the license or permit has been granted, or any regulation or law of the state so applicable; 
7.  Failure to continuously comply with all conditions required as precedent to the approval of the license or permit. 
(Prior code § 110.10) 
5.04.110 - Hearing. 
    Not less than three days nor more than ten (10) days prior to a hearing on the revocation of a license or permit, the council shall have served on the licensee or permittee either personally or on the person in charge of the place of activity operated under the license or permit, a notice of the time and place of the hearing and directing the licensee or permittee to show cause why the license or permit should not be revoked. 
(Prior code § 110.11) 
5.04.120 - Right of entry of city officials. 
    City officials may enter upon the premises where any licensed or permitted activity is being conducted for the purpose of inspection at any reasonable time. 
(Prior code § 110.12) 
Chapter 5.08 - AMUSEMENT ESTABLISHMENTS 
Sections: 
Article I. - Pool and Billiards 

5.08.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    "Amusements" means any pool table, billiard table, bagatelle table, pigeonhole table or game machines operated by coins or other metallic or wooden objects. 
    "Amusement establishment" means and includes any building or structure open to the public, the primary use of which is devoted to offering to the public the right to play "amusements" as defined in this section. An amusement establishment shall not include a building or structure which is devoted solely to offering to the public the right to play machines operated by coins or other metallic or wooden objects. A separate room, with separate entrance, located within an amusement establishment, if the use of such room is devoted entirely to offering to the public the right to play game machines operated by coins or other metallic or wooden objects, shall not be deemed an amusement establishment. 
(Prior code § 113.10) 
5.08.020 - License required. 
A.  No person, firm or corporation shall operate, maintain or conduct an amusement establishment open to the public without having first obtained a license therefor as required by this section. 
B.  All applications for such license shall state thereon the intended location of the place of business and the number and description of tables or games to be used therein. 
C.  The application shall be accompanied by a statement signed by the chief of police indicating the recommendations of the police department. 
D.  The granting of a license shall be evidenced by a sticker issued by the clerk-treasurer's office which shall immediately be prominently affixed upon the amusement device so licensed. Such stickers shall be issued annually upon payment of the license fee and shall be valid for the calendar year in which they are issued. There shall be no prorating of the license fee for a period of less than one year. 
(Prior code § 113.11) 
5.08.030 - Fees. 
    The annual fee for license for game tables as described in this chapter shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the first five tables, and an additional fee of forty dollars ($40.00) for each additional table. The annual fee for a license for game machines as described in this chapter shall be forty dollars ($40.00) for the first game machine, and an additional fee of forty dollars ($40.00) for each additional game machine. 
(Prior code § 113.12) 
5.08.040 - Location. 
    Any place containing machines or tables so licensed shall be on the ground floor, clearly visible from the street, with no curtains, blinds or other obstructions obstructing the view. Such place shall not have a second story or basement operated or used as an amusement establishment. 
(Prior code § 113.13) 
5.08.050 - Hours of operation. 
    Any place so licensed shall not be operated earlier than seven a.m. nor later than midnight on any day. Taverns, restaurants and retail stores shall be excluded from the provisions of this section. 
(Prior code § 113.14) 
5.08.060 - Exceptions. 
    This chapter shall not apply in any case where a pool table, game table, or game machine may be kept or used in a private family residence or in a building maintained for philanthropic, benevolent, educational or municipal park and recreation purposes. 
(Prior code § 113.15) 
5.08.070 - Restrictions upon minors. 
    No person under the age of sixteen (16) years may be permitted to be within or about an amusement establishment unless accompanied by a responsible adult, parent or guardian and if so accompanied, only between the hours of two p.m. and eleven p.m., Monday through Thursday (excepting holidays), and between the hours of two p.m. and twelve p.m. on Fridays (excepting holidays), and between the hours of seven a.m. and twelve midnight, Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. 
(Prior code § 113.16) 
5.08.080 - Issuance of license. 
    All applications for licenses required by this article shall be filed with the clerk-treasurer who shall submit it to the board of works and safety for approval or disapproval. If approved, the clerk-treasurer shall issue such license. 
(Prior code § 113.17) 
Article II. - Skating Rinks 

5.08.090 - License required. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to operate any skating rink for profit within the city without a license. 
B.  The fee for a license to operate a skating rink is twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Prior code § 113.20) 
5.08.100 - Approval by council. 
    The common council shall pass upon all applications for licenses under this article and shall hear and determine all questions as to the fitness of applicant, or propriety of locating business in the premises for which a license is sought. 
(Prior code § 113.21) 
5.08.110 - Hours of operation. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate or use any skating rink within the city between the hours of twelve p.m. and six a.m. 
(Prior code § 113.22) 
5.08.120 - Violation-Penalty. 
    The penalty for violation of this article shall be as set forth in Section 1.16.010 of this code and, in addition, revocation of all licenses granted under this article. 
(Prior code § 113.99) 
Chapter 5.12 - CABLE TELEVISION 
Sections: 

5.12.010 - Adoption of regulations. 
    The provisions of 47 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 76, Subpart N - Cable Rate Regulation, are adopted by reference and incorporated into this chapter as if fully set forth herein. A summary of those regulations are attached to Ordinance 94-3, passed 2-28-94, as Exhibit A. 
(Prior code § 99.01) 
5.12.020 - Procedure. 
    Said Subpart N, as supplemented in this chapter and as applicable to any cable rate regulation proceeding before the common council, as a franchising authority under 47 USC Section 543, shall govern proceeding. 
(Prior code § 99.02) 
5.12.030 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    "Cable operator" means any franchisee of the city under this chapter. 
    "Commission" means the Federal Communications Commission. 
    "FCC" means the Federal Communications Commission. 
    "Franchising authority" means the city. 
(Prior code § 99.03) 
5.12.040 - Procedure for consideration of the views of interested parties. 
A.  Any basic service, equipment or installation rate filing by a cable operator on the franchising authority under Subpart N shall contain a brief summary or description for publication purposes and shall include appropriate FCC forms and/or worksheets. 
B.  A cable operator shall make Subpart N filings with the city clerk. 
C.  Upon such filing, the city clerk shall forthwith place notice of such filing on the agenda for the next regularly scheduled meeting of the common council as an agenda item for the council to set a public hearing on such basic service, equipment or installation rate request. 
D.  Such hearing shall then be set by the council on a date at least ten (10) but not more than twenty-one (21) days thereafter. 
E.  Notice of the date, time and place of such hearing, together with a brief summary or description of the rate request, shall be published by the city clerk in a newspaper of general circulation at least ten (10) days prior to such hearing. 
F.  In the event additional days are taken under 47 CFR Section 76.933, such hearing shall be deemed continued until final regulatory action is taken by the council. 
(Prior code § 99.04) 
5.12.050 - Effect of amendments. 
    Any amendments to Subpart N as adopted by reference by Section 5.12.010 of this chapter shall be deemed effective as published by the FCC, including but not limited to effective dates; provided such amendments will not be enforced under this chapter absent ratification by the common council; provided further that no 47 CFR Section 76.943 fines shall be levied thereunder absent adoption by the common council. No gap in rate regulation authority shall be implied by or inferred from any failure of the council to anticipate or simultaneously adopt revisions as contemplated at 47 USC Section 543 (b)(2). 
(Prior code § 99.05) 
Chapter 5.16 - DANCE HALLS AND DRIVE-IN RESTAURANTS 
Sections: 

5.16.010 - Permit for dance halls-Application. 
A.  No person shall operate a dance hall in the city without a permit. The annual fee for a permit is five dollars ($5.00). 
B.  Any person desiring a permit to operate a dance hall shall file a written application with the common council, giving the specific location of the proposed business with the manner of carrying on of the business, together with the written consent of not less than eighty (80) percent of the number of freeholders owning real estate within three hundred (300) feet of the proposed place of business to be established. 
C.  The common council may change or modify the conditions under which the business may be operated as contained in the application before granting a permit, and the business, if established, shall be carried on in compliance with these conditions and permit. 
(Prior code § 113.01) 
5.16.020 - Location. 
    It is unlawful for any person to hereafter build, erect, locate, establish or maintain a dance hall or drive-in restaurant within three hundred (300) feet of any church, schoolhouse or post office building within the city. Any dance hall or drive-in restaurant hereafter located, built, erected or maintained in violation of this section is declared to be a nuisance and abatable as such. This section shall not apply to any place or business within the business or commercial district or industrial district as now or hereafter designated by the common council. 
(Prior code § 113.02) 
Chapter 5.20 - ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND SOLICITORS 
Sections: 

5.20.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    "Itinerant merchant" means any transient person who shall engage temporarily in the making or selling of any kind of goods, wares or merchandise, including the making and selling of photographs, within the city regardless of whether these goods, wares or merchandise are peddled from house to house or sold from any room, building, structure or lot rented or leased for the purpose of carrying on this business. 
    "Solicitor" means any person who goes from house to house or from place to place in the city, selling or taking orders for, or offering to sell or take orders for goods, wares, merchandise, services, or any article for future delivery. However, this term shall apply only to "solicitors" who demand, accept or receive payment or a deposit of money in advance of final delivery. 
(Prior code § 111.01) 
5.20.020 - License required-Exemptions. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of itinerant merchant or in the business of solicitor within the city without a license therefor. 
B.  The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to sales to dealers by commercial travelers, sales by producers of farm or dairy products or bona fide auction sales. 
(Prior code § 111.02) 
5.20.030 - License-Application. 
    Any person desiring to engage in the business of itinerant merchant or solicitor shall send a letter to the board of public works and safety informing the board of his or her intention to apply for a license to engage in such business. The person shall also make an application in writing to the clerk-treasurer for a license to engage in the business of itinerant merchant or solicitor, and both the letter and the application shall be filed at least seven days before the applicant shall be authorized to begin the business. The application shall state the name and residence of the applicant, the place where the business is to be conducted, the kind of goods to be sold and length of time for which a license is desired. 
(Prior code § 111.03) 
5.20.040 - Bond requirement. 
    The license application referred to in Section 5.20.030 of this chapter shall be accompanied by a bond in the penal sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) executed by a surety company or two responsible free holders residing within the city, or in lieu thereof or a cash bond of equal amount; conditioned that all goods, wares, merchandise or articles sold by the applicant will be as represented by him or her and that he or she will refund the purchase price of any goods, wares, merchandise or articles sold by him or her which are not as represented. Any person aggrieved by the action of any solicitor or itinerant merchant shall have a right of action on the bond for the recovery of money or damages or both. In the event a cash bond is deposited, it shall be retained by the city for ninety (90) days after the expiration of the license. 
(Prior code § 111.04) 
5.20.050 - License fees-Exemptions. 
A.  Upon the filing of the application and bond, and the approval of the bond, a license shall be issued by the clerk-treasurer to the applicant to begin business not less than seven days after the date of filing the application and bond, upon the payment of the following fees: for one day, ten dollars ($10.00); for one week, twenty-five dollars ($25.00); for one month, fifty dollars ($50.00); for one year, one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). All these license fees must be paid in advance and if any licensee desires to continue in business after the expiration of the license, a new license must be secured in the same manner and upon the same terms as the original license. 
B.  Any person exempted by the laws of this state from the payment of the license fees shall, before beginning a business present to the clerk-treasurer his or her credentials, showing that he or she is entitled to an exemption and shall execute and file a bond as provided in Section 5.20.040 of this chapter, and upon the approval of the bond he or she shall then receive a certificate from the clerk-treasurer authorizing him or her to engage in the business of itinerant merchant or solicitor within the city for any period not longer than one month. If at the end of a month the person desires to continue in that business, another certificate must be procured from the clerk-treasurer. 
(Prior code § 111.05) 
5.20.060 - Medical certificate required for food merchants. 
    Any person desiring to engage in the business of solicitor or itinerant merchant who sells fruit, vegetables, bread, pastries or other foodstuffs which have not been canned, shall, before receiving his or her license or certificate, present to the clerk-treasurer the certificate of a doctor of medicine, certifying that the persons handling the same are free from all venereal and transmittable diseases, and show that an examination has been made within thirty (30) days from the date of receiving the license. A new certificate shall be placed on file with the clerk-treasurer within thirty (30) days from the date of the first certificate so long as that person shall continue to do business under the license. No person shall transact any business of selling foodstuffs in the city under an itinerant merchant's license unless he or she shall have a physical examination certificate which is dated not more than thirty (30) days before. 
(Prior code § 111.06) 
5.20.070 - Orders to be in writing. 
    All orders taken by solicitors within the city shall be in writing, in duplicate, stating the terms thereof and the amount paid in advance, and one copy of the order shall be given to the purchaser. 
(Prior code § 111.07) 
Chapter 5.24 - MASSAGE PARLORS 
Sections: 

5.24.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    "Massage" means any method of treating the superficial soft parts of the body for remedial or hygienic purposes, consisting of rubbing, stroking, kneading, or tapping with the hands or instruments by a person of one sex on a person of the opposite sex. 
    "Massage parlor" means any building, room, place or establishment, other than a regularly licensed hospital or dispensary where nonmedical and nonsurgical manipulative exercises are practiced on the human body with or without the use of mechanical or bath devices by a person of one sex on a person of the opposite sex. 
    "Massage therapist" means any person who practices, administers or performs massages as defined by definition of massage. 
    "Sexual area" or "genital area" means the sexual or genital area of any person and shall include the genitals, pubic area, anus or perineum of person or the vulva or breast of a female. 
(Prior code § 114.01) 
5.24.020 - License required. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person or firm to operate, conduct or maintain a massage parlor without a license to operate such massage parlor issued by the office of the mayor or his or her designated agent. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person or firm licensed to operate a massage parlor to employ or permit any person to perform a massage unless such person is licensed as a massage therapist by the mayor or his or her authorized agent. 
C.  No license shall be required of any school licensed and regulated by the State Department of Public Instruction, by any regular four-year college or university, or by any Young Men's Christian Association or Young Women's Christian Association, licensed hospital or licensed nursing home, or by any licensed physician, osteopath, chiropractor, or physical therapist. 
(Prior code § 114.02) 
5.24.030 - License-Application. 
A.  The application for a license to operate a massage parlor shall contain the following information and shall be individually signed by the applicant: 
1.  Name of applicant and aliases; 
2.  Resident address of applicant and former addresses for the past five years; 
3.  Business address of the applicant; 
4.  Number of massage tables, shower stalls or other such individual units; 
5.  The age, date of birth and citizenship of the applicant, in the case of individuals, and of the manager and officers in the case of a corporation; 
6.  The names, addresses, ages, citizenship and designations of each person connected with the applicant's establishment; 
7.  Whether the applicant or its manager or officers have ever been previously engaged in operating a massage school, massage parlor, massage therapy clinic or bathhouse; 
8.  Whether any applicant, or in the case of a corporation, its managers, officers, directors or stockholders, have ever been convicted of any act of violence, moral turpitude, sex offense or prior violation of this chapter; 
9.  An agreement by the operator permitting inspection; 
10.  Type of license being applied for by the applicant. 
B.  There shall be filed a verified application for a massage therapist license by each individual who is employed in any establishment who is required by this chapter to be licensed. The application shall contain the following information: 
1.  Name and aliases; 
2.  Age, date of birth; 
3.  Address and former addresses for the past five years; 
4.  Citizenship; 
5.  Whether convicted of any public offense concerning an act of violence, moral turpitude, sex offense or prior violation of this chapter; 
6.  Nature of work performed. 
C.  Along with the aforesaid applications for licenses there shall be a certificate from a duly licensed medical practitioner, on a form prescribed by the county health department, certifying that the applicant is free from communicable diseases and that the examination has been made within thirty (30) days prior to the application for the license or permit herein sought. 
(Prior code § 114.03) 
5.24.040 - License fees. 
    The annual license fee for each person who operates or is employed by a massage parlor shall be determined in accordance with the following scale: 
A.  Licenses shall be required for all massage parlors, the fee for the license to be three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) annually; 
B.  Licenses shall be required for massage therapists, the fee for the license to be five hundred dollars ($500.00) annually for each therapist. 
(Prior code § 114.04) 
5.24.050 - Operation. 
A.  No massage parlor shall be operated or conducted within five hundred (500) feet of a church, school or residential area, or with a separate opening to living quarters. There must be a separate opening to living quarters and a separate entrance to the place of business. 
B.  All licensed operators or permit holders under this chapter shall display their licenses or permits in a visible location in their establishment. 
C.  All license or permit holders shall be subject to all other city ordinances, county ordinances, and state statutes and to regulations of various administrative bodies of the city, county and state. Violation of such regulations, ordinances or statutes shall be grounds for revocation of licenses or permits. 
D.  No person holding a license under this chapter shall administer to a person of the opposite sex, any massage, alcohol rub or similar treatment, fomentation, bath or electric or magnetic treatment, except on the signed order of a licensed physician, osteopath, chiropractor, podiatrist or registered physical therapist. A person shall neither cause or permit in or about his or her place of business or in connection with his or her business, any agent, employee, servant or other individual to administer any such treatment to any individual of the opposite sex. 
E.  All employees of establishments licensed under this chapter, including masseurs, masseuses and therapists, shall wear clean, nontransparent outer garments covering the sexual or genital areas. 
F.  The sexual or genital areas of patrons of establishments required to be licensed under this chapter must be covered with towels, clothes or undergarments when in the presence of an employee, masseur, masseuse or therapist. 
G.  No person in any establishment licensed under this chapter shall place his or her hand on or touch with any part of his or her body or fondle in any manner or massage a sexual or genital area of any other person. 
H.  No employee of an establishment licensed under this chapter shall perform, offer or agree to perform, any act which shall require the touching of the patron's genitals. 
I.  Every massage parlor shall be open for inspection during all business hours and at other reasonable times by police officers, health and fire inspectors and duly authorized representatives of the mayor on the showing of proper credentials by such persons. 
J.  Any massage parlor is prohibited from installing or maintaining any lock or similar device on the inside of any door of the business which cannot be operated by key or knob from the exterior of the door. 
(Prior code § 114.05) 
5.24.060 - Issuance or rejection of application-Qualifications. 
A.  The mayor or his or her authorized agent, before issuing any license provided for in this chapter, shall investigate the character of the applicant, and the officers, directors and managers of the business if it is a corporation. No license shall be issued if he or she shall find: 
1.  That any of the persons named in the application or any employee thereof are not persons of good moral character; 
2.  That any of the persons have previously been connected with any massage school, massage parlor, massage therapy clinic or bathhouse where the license therefor has heretofore been revoked or where any of the provisions of the law applicable to massage schools, massage parlors, massage therapy clinics or bathhouses have been violated; 
3.  That the premises sought to be so licensed fail to comply in any manner with the ordinances and laws applicable thereto. 
B.  All applicants for licenses to engage in the practice of massage therapy must submit a certificate or affidavit of their respective qualifications as to schooling, training and experience, and where and how obtained. 
(Prior code § 114.06) 
5.24.070 - Complaints. 
    Complaints of alleged violations of the provisions of this chapter may be made in writing to the mayor or his or her authorized agent, or the city police department. On learning of violations of the provisions of this chapter or related ordinances or laws, the mayor or his or her authorized agent shall hold a hearing to determine if any previously issued licenses shall be revoked. After a hearing thereon, if the mayor or his or her authorized agent should determine that the license shall be revoked, no refund of license or permit fee shall be due. 
(Prior code § 114.07) 
5.24.080 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Whoever violates any provisions of this chapter for which no penalty is otherwise provided, shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day that a violation occurs or continues. 
(Prior code § 114.99) 
Chapter 5.28 - PAWNBROKERS AND SECONDHAND DEALERS 
Sections: 
Article I. - Pawnbrokers[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-05, § 3, adopted June 3, 2013, repealed the former Art. I, §§ 5.28.010-5.28.120, and § 1 of said ordinance enacted a new Art. I as set out herein. The former Art. I pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Prior code, §§ 115.01-115.12. 

5.28.010. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    "Cash for gold" means any person engaged in the business of purchasing valuable items containing precious metals or stones for the exchange of cash or cash in the form of a check, excluding the purchase of precious metals or stones at wholesale. 
    "Customer" means: 
1.  Any person who as a part of his or her regular business deposits or pledges any personal property or thing of value with a licensee on condition of obtaining or recovering the property back again at a stipulated price, or any person who applies for sale of or sells any personal property or thing of value to a licensee; 
2.  Any person who shall be paid an advance on the consignment of any merchandise to be sold by a licensee; 
3.  Any person who shall sell pawn tickets to a licensee so that the licensee may redeem and resell that merchandise; 
4.  Any person who shall renegotiate, with a licensee, a pawn loan between themselves and other licensee. 
    "Licensee" means any person that has applied for or been issued a license regulated by this article. 
    "Minor" means a person under eighteen (18) years of age. 
    "Pawnbroker" means: 
1.  Any person who as a part of his or her regular business loans money on the deposit or pledge of any personal property or thing of value, on the condition of redelivering or selling the article back again at a stipulated price, other than choses in action, securities, or printed evidence of indebtedness; 
2.  Any person who as a part of his or her regular business practice shall buy pawn tickets from individuals so as to redeem and resell that merchandise; 
3.  Any person who shall as a part of his or her regular business renegotiate pawn loans between individuals and other pawnbrokers; 
4.  Any person who shall purchase precious metals or stones by or on behalf of a cash for gold or similar operation, excluding the purchase of precious metals or stones at wholesale; 
5.  This article does not apply to used car dealers and retailers who take in partial consideration of the purchase of a new item a used item which is the same type merchandise they normally sell new. 
    "Person" means any individual, limited liability company, sole proprietorship, partnership, trust, joint venture, corporation, unincorporated organization, or other form of entity, however organized. 
    "Pledge" means personal property deposited with a pawnbroker as security for a loan. 
    "Precious metals or stones" means any of several metals that have high economic value, including, but not limited to, silver, gold, and platinum; or containing gems, including, but not limited to, diamonds, rubies, or emeralds. 
    "Secondhand dealer" means: 
1.  Any person who as a part of his or her regular business buys or sells the following secondhand items: coins, currency, jewelry, comic books, trading cards, stamp collections, figurines or any item whose value increases over time; 
2.  This does not apply to used car dealers and retailers who take in partial consideration of the purchase of a new item a used item which is the same type merchandise they normally sell new; 
3.  This does not include pawnbrokers or cash for gold operations. 
    "Transaction" means: 
1.  Any sale, loan, pledge or deposit of any personal property or thing of value between a customer and a licensee as a part of the licensee's regular business; 
2.  Any advance payment on the consignment of any merchandise between a customer and a licensee; 
3.  Any sale of pawn tickets by a customer to a licensee for the purpose of redemption and resale of the pawned merchandise; 
4.  Any renegotiation of a pawn loan by a customer and a licensee of a pawn loan between the customer and any other licensed pawnbroker. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 6-3-2013) 
5.28.020 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of pawnbroker or cash for gold without first obtaining a license from the city clerk-treasurer and having complied with all current licensing requirements of IC 28-7-5-3 as amended. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 6-3-2013) 
5.28.030 - License fee. 
A.  The annual fee for a license required shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each place of business of the licensee. 
B.  Licenses shall be valid beginning January 1 and will expire December 31 of each year. 
C.  Regardless of the date obtained, the annual license will expire December 31 of each year. 
D.  Annual renewal of licenses shall be obtained no later than January 31. Late renewals will result in tripling the annual fee. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 6-3-2013) 
5.28.040 - License application. 
A.  All applicants for licenses shall first furnish to the city clerk-treasurer evidence of compliance with the requirements of section 5.28.050. Such evidence shall be in the form of a photograph (printed at a minimum of three (3) inches x five (5) inches) in which the installation of the recording device required by section 5.28.050 is clearly visible and identifiable, in addition to such other written information as the city clerk-treasurer, in his or her discretion, may require. 
B.  All applications for licenses shall be supported by affidavits of at least three (3) resident freeholders of the city stating that the applicant is of good moral character. 
C.  All applicants shall, as a condition for the granting of a license and on a portion of the application provided by the city clerk-treasurer, agree that in the event the applicant as licensee receives merchandise of any kind which is stolen, he or she claims no right, title or interest in or to the merchandise, and that upon request by law enforcement officers having jurisdiction over the location of his or her place of business, he or she will voluntarily surrender the merchandise to the possession of the investigating law enforcement agency who has reason to believe that the merchandise is stolen when given a receipt or notice of adverse claim for the same. 
D.  All applicants shall at the time of application or renewal show membership of the online reporting database used by the city police department. Refusal to participate may be grounds for denial of license or renewal of license. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 6-3-2013) 
5.28.050 - Photographic/video recording devices-Photographs required. 
A.  All licensees shall install and operate during the regular course of their business photographic or video recording devices for use in recording each customer transaction. 
B.  Such devices shall be maintained in good operating condition and be permanently mounted in such a manner as to take a full front photograph or video of the head and shoulders of each customer as he or she completes each transaction. The licensee shall furnish sufficient lighting to insure that the photographic/video image is identifiable. No licensee shall accept any article as collateral, security, for purchase or for resale unless the licensee makes a photographic or video recording, as provided in this article, of the person from whom the article is being received. 
C.  Every licensee under this article shall keep photographic/video records of each customer transaction as official records on file at the place of business for a period of thirty (30) days from the date of the transaction. Photographic/video records will be accessible by date and number of pawn ticket as required under this article and will be produced upon request to the city police department at all reasonable times when given a receipt for the same. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 6-3-2013) 
5.28.060 - Unlawful transactions. 
A.  It is unlawful and an infraction of this article for a licensee under this article to receive any articles in the course of business from any person who is in an intoxicated condition, a minor, one who cannot produce a photographic identification card, or who is known or suspected by the licensee to have acquired and be disposing of such articles unlawfully. 
B.  No pawnbroker shall accept as collateral security or for purchase any property of the type given manufacturer's serial numbers or other identifying insignia unless such property shall have plainly visible thereon the manufacturer's serial number or other identifying insignia. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 6-3-2013) 
5.28.070 - Record book to be kept. 
A.  Every licensee under this article shall keep a correct list in a book or computer program in which shall be legibly written an accurate description in the English language of all articles pawned and the amount of money loaned thereon; the time of the transaction; the name and address of the person pawning the articles; and the number of the pawn ticket issued therefore. 
B.  The records required to be kept by subsection A of this section shall be open to inspection at all reasonable times by the police or the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 6-3-2013) 
5.28.080 - Card record. 
A.  In addition to the record book and photographic/video recorded transactions required by this article, each licensee shall fill out a card, approved by the city police department, recording each article pawned. 
B.  Each card shall be filled out in its entirety, reflecting the following customer information: pawn ticket or transaction number; date and time of transaction; name and address (including city, state and zip code); government-issued identification number; date of birth; customer's signature; a complete description of all items pawned, including serial numbers, model numbers, manufacturer's name, and purchase price; a right thumb print or any other specified finger if the thumb is missing. The thumb print and card information will be applied to the card in a manner approved by the city police department and will not be blurred or obliterated. 
C.  Precious metals or stones received as part of any transaction shall be photographed in the condition they are received. Photograph shall be of clear resolution, shall be retained and preserved (printed or digital) on the business premises for a period of one year from the date of the transaction and shall be made available to city police department upon request. 
D.  In addition to the card record, record of pawned articles from the previous business day must be reported by entering data through the use of the online reporting database used by the city police department before the hour of twelve noon of each day. 
E.  The card records must be kept at the place of business and shall be open to inspection at all reasonable times by the city police department. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 6-3-2013) 
5.28.090 - Retention of acquired property. 
A.  All property received by a licensee under this article shall be held intact by the licensee for at least ten (10) days. 
B.  The licensee will keep the property in its possession for thirty (30) days or turn it over to the investigating law enforcement agency when given receipt or a notice of an adverse claim from said investigating law enforcement agency for the property. The property will be returned to the licensee subsequent to the expiration of the thirty (30) day period, provided that such a return of the property is consistent with all legal proceedings and court orders that might apply. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 6-3-2013) 
5.28.100 - Confidentiality of photographs. 
    All photographs taken in accordance with the provisions of section 5.28.050 and card records complied in accordance with section 5.28.080 shall be restricted, with respect to the access to such photographs and the use thereof, to law enforcement personnel for the purpose of investigations involving wanted persons and stolen property. Any use of the photographs by or for private individuals or their commercial concerns is expressly prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 6-3-2013) 
5.28.110 - Revocation of license or suspension. 
A.  Any license issued under this article may be revoked or suspended by the board of public works and safety by reason of a violation of any of the provisions set forth. 
B.  When the board of public works and safety hearing date is set, the licensee shall receive not less than ten (10) days' written notice from the clerk-treasurer, which notice shall contain charges made, as well as the time and place when the hearing will be held. 
C.  At the hearing, the licensee will be entitled to a reasonable opportunity to be heard and shall have the right to be represented by counsel. Proceedings shall be conducted under oath. 
D.  The board may revoke or suspend the license if found that: 
1.  The licensee has willfully violated or has been grossly negligent in violating this article or any rule, order or guidance document adopted by the city, which includes reporting requirements, or any other state or federal law, regulation, or rule applicable to the business of a pawnbroker; 
2.  The licensee does not meet the licensing qualifications set forth in this article; or 
3.  The licensee knowingly or intentionally made material misrepresentation to, or concealed material information from, the city. 
E.  When a license is revoked or suspended, the city shall enter an order to that effect and notify the licensee of: 
1.  The revocation or suspension; 
2.  If a suspension has been ordered the duration of the suspension; 
3.  The procedure for appealing the revocation or suspension; and 
4.  Any other terms and conditions that apply to the revocation or suspension, to include but not limited to, returning said license to the clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 6-3-2013) 
5.28.120 - Penalties. 
A.  Any violator of the article shall be subject to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day up to an annual maximum of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
B.  The city may, through its legal department or other appropriate agency, seek a temporary restraining order and/or permanent restraining order against the offender in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
C.  The city's remedies shall be cumulative and pursuit of one remedy shall not preclude another. 
D.  Willful or intentional disregard of this article shall entitle the city to collect from the violator its costs of attorney's fees, court costs, and other reasonable expenses incurred by the city in obtaining a restraining order or other necessary remedy. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 6-3-2013) 
Article II. - Dealers in Secondhand Goods 

5.28.130 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of buying, selling or in any way dealing with used goods of any kind without first obtaining a secondhand dealer's license therefrom from the city clerk-treasurer. Provided, that this article shall not apply to retailers who primarily sell unused goods who in the course of selling such unused goods occasionally receive used goods as partial consideration for the sale of such unused goods and dispose of the same by sale or otherwise. Also, this article does not apply to used car dealer/retailers who take in partial consideration of the purchase of a new item, a used item, which is the same type merchandise they normally sell new. 
(Prior code § 115.20) 
5.28.140 - License-Application. 
A.  All applications for licenses required by this article shall be submitted on forms provided by the city clerk-treasurer and the applicant shall provide all information requested thereon. 
B.  There shall be four classes of secondhand dealers' licenses, as follows: 
1.  Regular. A regular secondhand dealer's license may be granted to any person who sells or intends to sell secondhand goods from a fixed location for a period exceeding fifteen (15) consecutive days in a calendar year. 
2.  Transient. A transient secondhand dealer's license may be granted to any person who sells or intends to sell secondhand goods from various locations for a period not exceeding fifteen (15) consecutive days at any one specific location. Such license shall only be issued for, and valid at a location where, a person has been issued a group permit as defined herein, and such group permittee has sponsored the transient applicant. 
3.  Group. A group secondhand dealer's license may be granted to any person who sponsors a used goods show at any one location for a period not exceeding fifteen (15) consecutive days. Such group permittee shall be required to set out the names and addresses of each person the group applicant will allow to participate in the used goods show and such group applicant will be required to obtain a transient dealer's license for those persons that do not hold one. A transient license is required of each person other than the group licensee who participates in the used goods show. 
4.  Antique. An antique dealer designation may be given any of the above three classes of secondhand dealers' licenses upon the request of the applicant, who satisfactorily shows that he or she predominantly deals in what is commonly known as antiques or works of art; and the clerk-treasurer, in his or her discretion, may make such special designation upon payment of an additional fee (to that required of such secondhand dealer's license) of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
C.  Any person may apply for, and hold, more than one class of secondhand dealer's license at a time; provided that the issuance of one class of license shall not entitle an applicant to another class of license. 
(Prior code § 115.21) 
5.28.150 - License fees. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this article shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each place of business of the licensee. 
(Prior code § 115.22) 
5.28.160 - Card record for police. 
A.  In addition to the record book required by this article, all licensees under this article shall fill out one of the cards prescribed by this section for each article pawned. The licensee shall fill out the front of each card in its entirety and the description of the customer on the back. The customer shall write in his or her own handwriting his or her name and address on the back of the card and place his or her right thumbprint in the space provided. If the right thumb is missing, any of the customer's fingerprints may be used. The thumbprint shall be made in the manner approved by the police and shall not be blurred or obliterated. 
B.  The back side of each of the cards prescribed by subsection A of this section shall be in the following form: 
Signature _____ 
Address _____ 
Description of Customer-To be filled out by dealer _____ 
Sex  ____________ Age  ____________ 
Height  ____________ ft.  ____________ in. 
Weight  ____________  lbs. 
Race or Nationality _____ 
Clothing _____ 
Complexion _____ 
Right Thumbprint 
C.  Before the hour of twelve noon of each day, each licensee under this article shall deliver all of the cards filled out on the previous business day, pursuant to the requirements of this section, to the chief of police. 
(Prior code § 115.23) 
5.28.170 - Retention of acquired property. 
    All property received by a licensee under this article shall be held intact by the licensee for at least seven days after the card report required by this article is delivered to the chief of police. Whenever any licensee receives written notice, either from the police department or from an individual, that someone is maintaining a claim of right to possession of the property adverse to the licensee, the licensee shall keep the property in his or her possession or turn it over to the police if so required by the chief of police. Once notice of an adverse claim to property has been given under this section, the property shall be held for a period of twenty (20) days, during which legal proceedings may be commenced to determine who is entitled to the property. If the matter is not settled or legal proceedings have not been commenced within twenty (20) days, the property shall be returned to the licensee by the police if held by them, and the licensee may dispose of the property, as he or she sees fit. 
(Prior code § 115.24) 
Chapter 5.32 - TAXICABS[2] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-10, §§ 1-12, adopted Aug. 19, 2013, amended Ch. 5.32 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 5.32, §§ 5.32.010-5.32.060, pertained to taxicabs, and derived from Ord. 01-30, §§ 2-7. 

5.32.010 - Definitions of taxicab.
